Most probiotic products today are developed with Bifidobacteria, Lactobacilli, and other lactic acid bacteria, such as Lactococci and Streptococci who prevent microbiota recovery..<br />\n<br />\nAncient Ayurveda used nano silver and nano gold to selectively and intelligently target harmful bacteria and viruses \u2013based on electric charge ..<br />\n<br />\nPeople who take high doses of antibiotics tend to lose many of their normal gut bacteria, allowing a naturally antibiotic-resistant species called Clostridium difficile to overgrow and cause severe gastric problems, especially chronic diarrhea.<br />\n<br />\nCONTINUED TO 2--</div>\n</div>\n<div style=\"font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; font-size: medium;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 24px;\"></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; margin-left: 36px; margin-top: 1em;\">\n<div class=\"comment-thread inline-thread\" id=\"c4736503402384504379-rt\" style=\"background-color: #eeeeee; margin: 8px 0px; padding: 0.5em 1em;\">\n<ol class=\"thread-chrome thread-expanded\" id=\"c4736503402384504379-ra\" style=\"list-style-type: none; padding: 0px;\">\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"c4346019654972987138\" style=\"border-bottom: 0px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 16px 0px 0px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2019/03/questions-from-capt-ajit-vadakayil-for.html?showComment=1553610700399#c4346019654972987138\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">March 26, 2019 at 8:01 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nCONTINUED FROM 1--<br />\n<br />\nObviously, trying to treat this problem with antibiotics only makes it worse. However, it has been successfully treated by giving the patients fecal transplants.. Fecal microbiome is not the same as the gut microbiome<br />\n<br />\nGandhi could not function without fecal transplants.. This is one of the reasons why two gut healthy naked underage girls slept with Gandhi under the same blanket..<br />\n<br />\nThe idea is that the stool from the donor contains a healthful mix of gut bacteria that can seed the intestine of the patient, bringing healthful results. Donor stool may be introduced into the colon via an enema<br />\n<br />\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i6RBfoITbls<br />\n<br />\nThe clash is over the future of fecal microbiota transplants, or F.M.T., a 6200 year old remedy in Charaka Samhita has proved remarkably effective in treating Clostridioides difficile, a debilitating bacterial infection that kills 41,000 beef eating Americans a year.<br />\n<br />\nThe first principle of medicine is do no harm, and there is ZILCH record of F.M.T.\u2019s adverse effects.<br />\n<br />\nTHE WHITE BASTARDS HAVE PATENTED FMT..<br />\n<br />\nAYURVEDA HAS ZERO SIDE EFFECTS ..<br />\n<br />\nKOSHER EVIL PHARMA DOES NOT LIKE FMT AS THEY STAND TO LOSE TWO BILLION USD A YEAR...<br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</ol>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/9yPjoh9YJMk/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/9yPjoh9YJMk?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-WXTAzV9eqJs/XJrb20x8ilI/AAAAAAABgXQ/a0MnMAoAs1A3rWHSNPRS_38grOAWh52fQCLcBGAs/s1600/24022-004sd-8EBB6780.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"243\" data-original-width=\"593\" height=\"262\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-WXTAzV9eqJs/XJrb20x8ilI/AAAAAAABgXQ/a0MnMAoAs1A3rWHSNPRS_38grOAWh52fQCLcBGAs/s640/24022-004sd-8EBB6780.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plant nutrient\navailability is affected by soil pH, which is a measure of the hydrogen ion\nactivity in the soil solution. Soil pH is a function of many soil forming\nfactors, and is generally lower (more acid) where weathering is more advanced.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microbial activity in\nsoils may release nutrients from minerals or organic matter for use by plants\nand other microorganisms, sequester (incorporate) them into living cells, or\ncause their loss from the soil by volatilisation (loss to the atmosphere as\ngases) or leaching.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-nmEdiImyoTo/XJrcoCJ3XMI/AAAAAAABgXY/stSE-FkG2dwCJafl1k5XptTRsdnLfBTygCLcBGAs/s1600/Soil-Profile-Sogggil-Horizon-soil-layers.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"480\" data-original-width=\"570\" height=\"538\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-nmEdiImyoTo/XJrcoCJ3XMI/AAAAAAABgXY/stSE-FkG2dwCJafl1k5XptTRsdnLfBTygCLcBGAs/s640/Soil-Profile-Sogggil-Horizon-soil-layers.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil formation, or pedogenesis,\nis the combined effect of physical, chemical, biological and anthropogenic\nprocesses working on soil parent material. Soil is said to be formed when\norganic matter has accumulated and colloids are washed downward, leaving\ndeposits of clay, humus, iron oxide, carbonate, and gypsum, producing a\ndistinct layer called the B horizon. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is a somewhat\narbitrary definition as mixtures of sand, silt, clay and humus will support\nbiological and agricultural activity before that time. These constituents are\nmoved from one level to another by water and animal activity. As a result,\nlayers (horizons) form in the soil profile. The alteration and movement of\nmaterials within a soil causes the formation of distinctive soil horizons. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A soil horizon is a\nlayer parallel to the soil surface, whose physical, chemical and biological\ncharacteristics differ from the layers above and beneath.&nbsp;&nbsp; The uppermost soil layer (not including\nsurface litter) is termed the A horizon.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is a weathered layer that\ncontains an accumulation of humus (decomposed, dark-coloured, carbon-rich\nmatter) and microbial biomass that is mixed with small-grained minerals to form\naggregate structures.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-XYFyCWBZZ9s/XJrdQzkI0fI/AAAAAAABgXg/1KcEDbXTD1wzIQ3Kkbmt9JF9jMc6xsbZACLcBGAs/s1600/layers-soil-education-diagram-mineral-particles-sand-humus-stones-clay-tevvmplate-banners-pages-vector-natural-fertilizer-103704800.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"1390\" data-original-width=\"1300\" height=\"640\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-XYFyCWBZZ9s/XJrdQzkI0fI/AAAAAAABgXg/1KcEDbXTD1wzIQ3Kkbmt9JF9jMc6xsbZACLcBGAs/s640/layers-soil-education-diagram-mineral-particles-sand-humus-stones-clay-tevvmplate-banners-pages-vector-natural-fertilizer-103704800.jpg\" width=\"598\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Below A lies the B horizon. In mature soils\nthis layer is characterized by an accumulation of clay (small particles less\nthan 0.002 mm in diameter) that has either been deposited out of percolating\nwaters or precipitated by chemical processes involving dissolved products of\nweathering.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Clay endows B horizons with an array of diverse structural features\n(blocks, columns, and prisms) formed from small clay particles that can be\nlinked together in various configurations as the horizon evolves.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Below the A and B\nhorizons is the C horizon, a zone of little or no humus accumulation or soil\nstructure development. The C horizon often is composed of unconsolidated parent\nmaterial from which the A and B horizons have formed. It lacks the\ncharacteristic features of the A and B horizons and may be either relatively\nunweathered or deeply weathered. At some depth below the A, B, and C horizons\nlies consolidated rock, which makes up the R horizon.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/9uMPuF5oCPA/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/9uMPuF5oCPA?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2011/09/american-pollution-capt-ajit-vadakayil.html\"><span style=\"background-color: lime; font-size: large;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2011/09/american-pollution-capt-ajit-vadakayil.html</span></a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/QZR2_gijRJY/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/QZR2_gijRJY?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/ss31DIBw-1A/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/ss31DIBw-1A?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During the humification\nprocess, microbes secrete sticky gum-like mucilages; these contribute to the\ncrumb structure (tilth) of the soil by holding particles together, and allowing\ngreater aeration of the soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The world has woken up\nto the fact that the chemical fertilizers and pesticides not only have adverse\neffects on soil but also are harmful for human health. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">How your food is grown\nor raised can have a major impact on your mental and emotional health as well\nas the environment. Organic foods often have more beneficial nutrients, such as\nantioxidants, than their conventionally-grown counterparts and people with\nallergies to foods, chemicals, or preservatives often find their symptoms\nlessen or go away when they eat only organic foods.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pesticides are chemical\npreparations used to kill fungal or animal pests. Over 98.5% of sprayed\ninsecticides and 96% of herbicides reach a destination other than their target\nspecies, because they are sprayed or spread across entire agricultural fields.</span>&nbsp;</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Runoff\n&nbsp;carry pesticides into aquatic\nenvironments while wind can carry them to other fields, grazing areas, human\nsettlements and undeveloped areas, potentially affecting other species.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Over\ntime, repeated application increases pest resistance, while its effects on\nother species can facilitate the pest's resurgence.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The extensive use of\npesticides in agricultural production &nbsp;degrade and damage the community of\nmicroorganisms living in the soil..</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many of the chemicals\nused in pesticides are persistent soil contaminants, whose impact &nbsp;endure for decades and adversely affect soil\nconservation.. The use of pesticides decreases the general biodiversity in the\nsoil. Not using the chemicals results in higher soil quality.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">LOSS OF ORGANIC MATTER\nAND MICROBES IN THE TOP SOIL PREVENTS THE APPLIED TOXIC CHEMICALS FROM BREAKING\nDOWN..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">MORE ORGANIC MATTER IN\nTHE SOIL ALLOWS FOR HIGHER WATER RETENTION.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">DON\u2019T EVER THINK THAT\nALL WATER IN THE GANGES DOWNRIVER IS MELTED HIMALAYAN ICE.. THIS WATER HAS\nLEACHED FROM THE SOIL ON EITHER SIDE OF THE RIVER BANKS..&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">RAPE OF SOIL BY CHENICAL FERTILISERS AND\nPESTICIDES CAUSES SEVERE LOSS OF WATER HOLDING CAPACITY..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Degradation and\nsorption are both factors which influence the persistence of pesticides in\nsoil. Depending on the chemical nature of the pesticide, such processes control\ndirectly the transportation from soil to water, and in turn to air and our\nfood. Breaking down organic substances, degradation, involves interactions\namong microorganisms in the soil.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sorption affects bioaccumulation of\npesticides which are dependent on organic matter in the soil. Weak organic acids\nare weakly sorbed by soil, because of pH and mostly acidic structure. Sorbed\nchemicals become less accessible to microorganisms.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Aging mechanisms are poorly\nunderstood but as residence times in soil increase, pesticide residues become\nmore resistant to degradation and extraction as they lose biological activity<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogen fixation,\nwhich is required for the growth of higher plants, is hindered by pesticides in\nsoil.&nbsp; The insecticides &nbsp;interfere with legume-rhizobium chemical\nsignaling</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Reduction of this\nsymbiotic chemical signaling results in reduced nitrogen fixation and thus\nreduced crop yields.&nbsp; Root nodule\nformation in these plants saves the world economy 14 billion USD in synthetic\nnitrogen fertilizer every year<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Symbiotic nitrogen\nfixation occurs in plants that harbor nitrogen-fixing bacteria within their\ntissues. The best-studied example is the association between legumes and\nbacteria in the genus Rhizobium. ... A symbiotic relationship in which both\npartners benefits is called mutualism.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even the agriculture\nscientists agree with the view that regular use of chemical fertilizers leads\nto a situation when land ultimately becomes unproductive and barren because of\ndestruction of microbes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pesticides kill bees\nand are strongly implicated in pollinator decline, the loss of species that\npollinate plants, including through the mechanism of Colony Collapse Disorder,\nin which worker bees from a beehive or western honey bee colony abruptly\ndisappear. Application of pesticides to crops that are in bloom kill honeybees\nwhich act as pollinators.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2011/09/queen-bee-and-darwin-capt-ajit.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2011/09/queen-bee-and-darwin-capt-ajit.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pesticides have direct\nharmful effect on plant including poor root hair development, shoot yellowing\nand reduced plant growth..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pesticides can\neliminate some animals' essential food sources, causing the animals to\nrelocate, change their diet or starve. Residues can travel up the food chain;\nfor example, birds can be harmed when they eat insects and worms that have\nconsumed pesticides. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Earthworms digest\norganic matter and increase nutrient content in the top layer of soil. They\nprotect human health by ingesting decomposing litter and serving as\nbioindicators of soil activity. Pesticides have had harmful effects on growth\nand reproduction on earthworms.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some\npesticides can bioaccumulate, or build up to toxic levels in the bodies of\norganisms that consume them over time, a phenomenon that impacts species high\non the food chain especially hard.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Studies have revealed that\n72 million birds are killed by pesticides in the United States alone each year.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fish and other aquatic\nbiota are harmed by pesticide-contaminated water.&nbsp; &nbsp;Pesticide\nsurface runoff into rivers and streams are highly lethal to aquatic life,\nsometimes killing all the fish in a particular stream..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Application of\nherbicides to bodies of water cause fish kills when the dead plants decay and\nconsume the water's oxygen, suffocating the fish. Herbicides such as copper\nsulfite that are applied to water to kill plants are toxic to fish and other\nwater animals at concentrations similar to those used to kill the plants.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Repeated exposure to sublethal doses of some pesticides cause physiological and\nbehavioral changes that reduce fish populations, such as abandonment of nests\nand broods, decreased immunity to disease and decreased predator avoidance<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Application of\nherbicides to bodies of water kill plants on which fish depend for their\nhabitat.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pesticides &nbsp;accumulate in bodies of water to levels that\nkill off zooplankton, the main source of food for young fish. Pesticides also\nkill off insects on which some fish feed, causing the fish to travel farther in\nsearch of food and exposing them to greater risk from predators.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pesticides &nbsp;enter the body through inhalation of aerosols,\ndust and vapor that contain pesticides; through oral exposure by consuming\nfood/water; and through skin exposure by direct contact.&nbsp; Pesticides secrete into soils and groundwater\nwhich can end up in drinking water, and pesticide spray can drift and pollute\nthe air.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Persistent,\nbioaccumulative and toxic substances (PBTs) are a class of compounds that have\nhigh resistance to degradation from abiotic and biotic factors, high mobility\nin the environment and high toxicity. Because of these factors PBTs have been\nobserved to have a high order of bioaccumulation and biomagnification, very\nlong retention times in various media..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">PBTs &nbsp;have a high environmental mobility relative to\nother contaminants mainly due to their resistance to degradation (persistence).\nThis allows PBTs to travel far and wide in both the atmosphere and in aqueous\nenvironments.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The low degradation rates of PBTs allow these chemicals to be\nexposed to both biotic and abiotic factors while maintaining a relatively\nstable concentration. Another factor that makes PBTs especially dangerous are\nthe degradation products which are often relatively as toxic as the parent compound.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The bioaccumulative\nability of PBTs follows suit with the persistence attribute by the high\nresistance to degradation by biotic factors, especially with in organisms.\nBioaccumulation is the result of a toxic substance being taken up at a higher\nrate than being removed from an organism.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For PBTs this is caused mainly by a\nresistance to degradation, biotic and abiotic. PBTs usually are highly\ninsoluble in water which allows them to enter organisms at faster rates through\nfats and other nonpolar regions on an organism.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bioaccumulation of a toxicant lead\nto biomagnification through a trophic web which has resulted in massive concern\nin areas with especially low trophic diversity. Biomagnification results in\nhigher trophic organisms accumulating more PBTs than those of lower trophic\nlevels through consumption of the PBT contaminated lower trophic organisms<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2012/07/chemical-hazards-on-chemical-tankers.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2012/07/chemical-hazards-on-chemical-tankers.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil microorganisms do\nmuch more than nourish plants. Just as the microbes in the human body both aid\ndigestion and maintain our immune system, soil microorganisms both digest\nnutrients and protect plants against pathogens and other threats.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The microbial community\nin the soil, like in the human biome, provides \u201cinvasion resistance\u201d services\nto its symbiotic partner. We disturb this association at our peril .&nbsp; The alarming increase in autoimmune diseases\nin the West owe to a disruption in the ancient relationship between our bodies\nand their \u2018old friends\u2019\u200a\u2014\u200athe microbial symbionts with whom we coevolved.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Not only do soil\nmicroorganisms nourish and protect plants, they play a crucial role in\nproviding many \u201cecosystem services\u201d that are absolutely critical to human\nsurvival. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The living soil is the\nEarth\u2019s most valuable ecosystem, providing ecological services such as climate\nregulation, mitigation of drought and floods, soil erosion prevention, and\nwater filtration, worth trillions of dollars each year. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even soil microbes need\ncarbon to flourish, which is why slow and steady carbon depletion from our\nsoils will inevitably lead to ecological collapse.&nbsp; &nbsp;Deprived of carbon and critical microbes,\nsoils become sterile, devoid of the microbial ecosystem. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plants draw CO2 out of\nthe atmosphere and into the ground through the process of photosynthesis, and\nthis is a far more efficient method than any carbon-reduction scheme man has\nbeen able to come up with.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The plants convert this CO2 into a carbon fuel used\nto stimulate and promote their own growth. Up to 42% of that carbon fuel also\ngoes to the roots of the plant, where it\u2019s leaked out into the soil.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nutrient cycling is the\nexchange of nutrients between the living and nonliving parts of the ecosystem. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microorganisms are\nresponsible for the degradation of organic matter, which controls the release\nof plant nutrients, but is also important for the maintenance of soil structure\nand sustainability of soil quality for plant growth.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microbial activity in soil\nis also responsible for carbon losses to the atmosphere through respiration and\nmethanogenesis, and microorganisms are required for remediation, through\ndegradation of organic pollutants and immobilisation of heavy metals, providing\nobvious examples of improving soil quality.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus all microbiological activity\nin soil contributes to cycling of nutrients and other ecosystem functions and\nall soil functions contribute to ecosystem services.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nutrient cycling\ncan be assessed by measuring the following indicators:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fertility Indicators\nincluding mineral nitrogen, potentially mineralizable nitrogen, soil nitrate,\nsoil test phosphorus, potassium, sulfur, calcium, magnesium, boron, and zinc<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic Matter\nIndicators including C:N ratio, decomposition, microbial biomass carbon,\nparticulate organic matter, soil enzymes, soil organic matter, total organic\ncarbon and total organic matter<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil Reaction\nIndicators including soil pH<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil is the major\n\"switching yard\" for the global cycles of carbon, water, and\nnutrients. Carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, and many other nutrients are stored,\ntransformed, and cycled through soil.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Decomposition\nby soil organisms is at the center of the transformation and cycling of\nnutrients through the environment.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Decomposition liberates carbon and nutrients\nfrom the complex material making up life forms-putting them back into\nbiological circulation so they are available to plants and other organisms.\nDecomposition also degrades compounds in soil that would be pollutants if they\nentered ground or surface water.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Decomposition is a\nstepwise process involving virtually all soil organisms. Arthropods and\nearthworms chew the material and mix it with soil. A few fungi may break apart\none complex compound into simpler components, then bacteria can attack the\nnewly created compounds, and so on. Each organism gets energy or nutrients from\nthe process.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Usually, but not always, compounds become simpler after each step.\nThe portion of plant and animal residue that is not broken down plays a crucial\nrole in soil. It is transformed into the highly complex organic compounds\ncalled humic substances that can persist in soil for centuries and are\nimportant to soil structure and nutrient storage.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">More carbon is stored in soil than\nin the atmosphere and above-ground biomass combined. Soil carbon is in the form\nof organic compounds originally created through photosynthesis in which plants\nconvert atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) into plant matter made of organic\ncarbon compounds, such as carbohydrates, proteins, oils, and fibers.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\norganic compounds enter the soil system when plants and animals die and leave\ntheir residue in or on the soil. Immediately, soil organisms begin consuming\nthe organic matter, extracting energy and nutrients and releasing water, heat,\nand CO2 back to the atmosphere. Thus, if no new plant residue is added to the\nsoil, soil organic matter will gradually disappear.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If plant residue is added\nto the soil at a faster rate than soil organisms convert it to CO2, carbon will\ngradually be removed from the atmosphere and stored (sequestered) in the soil.\nCultivation aerates the soil, triggering increased biological activity, and\ntherefore rapid decomposition, loss of soil organic matter, and release of CO2\ninto the atmosphere..</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nannual loading with artificial fertilisers &nbsp;is nowmore than 10.1 million tonnes of\nphosphorus and &nbsp;62 million tonnes of\nnitrogen per year. Typically, if the local plant community cannot take up the\nadded nutrient load, the nutrients move through groundwater, ditches, and\nstreams into lakes and oceans.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Throughout\nthe world, lakes and marine shorelines become \u201cover-productive\u201d (eutrophic)\nwhere a few plant or bacteria species feast on the nutrients and choke out\nother lifeforms. Eutrophication can create dead zones and putrid lakes.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fish\nand amphibians can die out, leaving festering swamps. In just 55 years of the\nadvent of the&nbsp; desh drohi GREEN\nREVOLUTION 90% : of our lakes and water bodies are. When algae blooms die off,\nthey deplete oxygen, killing other organisms.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">NGT , Environment Ministry and\nour Think Tanks are packed with people who have shit for brains.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The disruption\nof Earth\u2019s nutrient cycles remains MORE urgent than global heating and\nbiodiversity loss.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cHuman alteration of\nthe global nitrogen cycle,\u201d showed that human disruption of the nitrogen cycle\nhas:---<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Doubled the rate of nitrogen input into\nterrestrial ecosystems<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Increased the greenhouse gas N2O globally,\ncontributing to photochemical smog<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Depleted calcium and potassium in soils,\nundermining long</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria math&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2010</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">term\nsoil fertility<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Contributed to acidification of soils,\nstreams, and lakes&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Increased the eutrophication of lakes, rivers,\nestuaries, and coastal oceans<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Diminished biological diversity<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Reduced coastal marine fisheries<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">We can reverse the\ntrend of increasing marine dead zones and eutrophic lakes. To achieve this,\nhowever, we must accept the evidence that nature\u2019s bounty comes with limits<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Miner microbes make a\nkind of \u201cbacterial goo\u201d \u2013 scientifically called an \u201cexudate\u201d. The goo has a\nspecial pH and other key characteristics specially formulated to bind and\nextract nutrients like phosphorus, calcium, and potassium. All of these\nminerals are needed for healthy plants and good crop yields.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A specific group of these\n\u201cmining\u201d microorganisms is called mycorrhizal fungi. Mycorrhizal fungi form\nspecial symbiotic relationships with plant roots. They connect with plant roots\nto provide access to the freshly-released nutrients. In return, the plant roots\nprovide the fungi with tasty, energy-rich carbon that the fungi use for growth\nin an otherwise desolate area of the soil environment.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The final type of\nmicrobes are the \u201crefiners.\u201d Refiner microbes, a class of bacteria called\nRhizobia, are able to take nitrogen from the air and process it into a form\nusable by the plant. These \u201cnitrogen-fixing\u201d bacteria take inert nitrogen gas\nin the atmosphere (N2 gas) and convert it to the plant-available ammonia and\nother nitrogen-rich organic compounds.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Generally, refiners\nonly live in special root formations called \u201cnodules\u201d of legume plants.\nPeanuts, alfalfa, clover, beans, and lentils, are all legumes. They can all\nform this symbiotic relationships with Rhizobia.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The legumes house the Rhizobia\nand provide them with energy-rich compounds for food. Due to this special\nsymbiotic relationship, legumes make for great cover-crops in agricultural\nsettings.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The dead tissues of legumes (re-introduced to the soil for future\nplant use by the recyclers!) are nitrogen-rich. This nitrogen-rich plant\nmaterial can provide nitrogen to the next planted crop. This means that the\nfarmer is not required to spend as much time, money, and energy applying\nnitrogen fertilizers.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-6kcHvVQuD5k/XJu6omhn3TI/AAAAAAABgX0/Wud7W_BL8HQwC-j2S1JWHaZOxwmFYTfAwCLcBGAs/s1600/biochar-projbduction-and-uses-dr-reddy-15-728.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"546\" data-original-width=\"728\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-6kcHvVQuD5k/XJu6omhn3TI/AAAAAAABgX0/Wud7W_BL8HQwC-j2S1JWHaZOxwmFYTfAwCLcBGAs/s640/biochar-projbduction-and-uses-dr-reddy-15-728.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A mulch is usually, &nbsp;organic in nature.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mulch is a material\nplaced on the soil surface to maintain moisture, reduce weed growth, mitigate\nsoil erosion and improve soil conditions. Mulching (installing mulches) can\nhelp to improve crop yield and optimise water use.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Typical\nmaterials for organic mulching are straw, leaves, cut grass, wood chips, peat,\ncut branches or the left over of old harvested crops and various types of\ncompost</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The microbes that work\nin the recycling role use the organic carbon in the organic matter as an energy\nsource (food). Recycling frees up nutrients like nitrogen, potassium, and\nphosphorus that are important to plant health. The importance of these\nrecycling microbes cannot be overstated; they turn the world\u2019s refuse into the\nbuilding blocks of life. The maintenance of plant-life would be nearly\nimpossible without these hard-working organisms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil biologists measure\nhow plants and microbes absorb nutrients, and incorporate them into organic\nmatter, which is the basis for the carbon cycle. There are two main processes.\nImmobilization is when soil organisms take up mineral nutrients from the soil\nand transform them into microbial and plant tissues. Immobilization in soil\nscience is the conversion of inorganic compounds to organic compounds by\nmicro-organisms or plants, by which it is prevented from being accessible to\nplants<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The opposite process is\nmineralization, which is what happens when organism die and release nutrients\nfrom their tissues. This process is rapidly changing, and very important in\nproviding nutrients for plants to grow. The carbon cycle and nitrogen cycle are\nboth very important to soil microbiologists.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mineralization\nincreases the bioavailability of the nutrients that were in the decomposing\norganic compounds, most notably, because of their quantities, nitrogen,\nphosphorus, and sulphur. Whether the decomposition of an organic compound will\nresult in mineralization or immobilization is dependent on its concentration\nproportionate to that of the carbon in the organic matter. If the concentration\nof a specific element exceeds the needs of the decomposer for biosynthesis or\nstorage then it will mineralize.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Whether nitrogen\nmineralizes or immobilizes depends on the carbon-to-nitrogen ratio (C:N ratio)\nof the decomposing organic matter.&nbsp; &nbsp;In general organic matter contacting soil has\ntoo little nitrogen to support the biosynthetic needs of the decomposing soil\nmicrobial population.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If the C:N ratio of the decomposing organic matter is\nabove circa 30:1 then the decomposing microbes may absorb nitrogen in mineral\nform as, e. g., ammonium or nitrates. This mineral nitrogen is said to be\nimmobilized. This may reduce the concentration of inorganic nitrogen in the\nsoil and thus the nitrogen available to plants.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As carbon dioxide is\nreleased during the generation of energy in decomposition, a process\ndenominated \"catabolism\", the C:N ratio of the organic matter\ndecreases. When the C:N ratio is less than circa 25:1, further decomposition\ncauses mineralization by the simultaneous release of inorganic nitrogen as\nammonium.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the decomposition of organic matter is complete, the mineralized\nnitrogen therefrom adds to that already present in the soil, and therefore\nincreases the total mineral nitrogen in the soil.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plant roots leak a lot\nof organic substances into the soil from dead materials. These provide food for\nthe microorganisms, and create zones of activity around the root called the\nrhizosphere. In this zone, plant growth or toxic substances can be produced,\nbut most of these organisms are benefical.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteria are organisms that have only one cell\nand are, therefore, microscopic. There are anywhere from 100 million to one\nbillion bacteria in just a teaspoon of moist, fertile soil. They are\ndecomposers, eating dead plant material and organic waste.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By doing this, the\nbacteria release nutrients that other organisms could not access. The bacteria\ndo this by changing the nutrients from inaccessible to usable forms. The\nprocess is essential in the nitrogen cycle.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">We can see that healthy\nsoils contain enormous numbers of microbes and substantial quantities of\nmicrobial biomass. This translates into an enormous potential for microbial\nactivity when soil conditions (available carbon sources, moisture, aeration,\ntemperature, acidity/alkalinity and available inorganic nutrients, such as\nnitrogen), are favourable.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The potential for activity must be stressed because,\nunder normal situations, the microbial population does not receive a constant\nsupply of readily-available substrates to sustain prolonged high rates of growth.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Almost all soil\norganisms (except some bacteria) need the same things that we need to live:\nfood, water and oxygen. They eat a carbon-based food source, which provides all\ntheir nutrients, including nitrogen and phosphorus.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">They require a moist habitat,\nwith access to oxygen in the air spaces in soil. These reasons explain why 75\nper cent of soil organisms are found in the top five centimetres of soil. It\nalso explains, however, why many of our agricultural soil microorganism\npopulations are deplete<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteria work to\naccelerate the breakdown of organic matter into inorganic material. This\nprocess is called nutrient recycling. Microorganisms are excellent recyclers of\nsoil nutrients and minerals for improved plant uptake.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A majority of nutrients\nare present in the soil in an insoluble form, unavailable for plant use.\nMicrobes are the only organisms on earth that are able to convert them into\nplant useable forms for improved crop yield and soil health.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Generally, microbes\ngrow best in soils that have a neutral pH (7.0), a balance of air and water\nfilled pore space and abundant organic substrates.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microbes live\nthroughout the entire season and then start to gradually decline in number\nafter you have harvested, as there is less sugar in the soil. Most of the\nbacteria will become dormant spores,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Over-used and\nover-fertilized soils tend to lose their microorganisms. They are also loss due\nto , floods, drought and freeze. Soils under these conditions can see up to 99%\nloss in their microorganisms which has a major role in the health of your soil\nand plants..&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Photosynthetic bacteria (called cyanobacteria)\nproduce 50% of the oxygen we breathe ..&nbsp; Half of the oxygen we\nbreath is a result of microbes that lived billions of years ago.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-ZFJVO9rRbAc/XJy543zqECI/AAAAAAABgYk/dF8Yj0OJsyk3kxJG062UVuGTBUnIcT9fwCLcBGAs/s1600/dddanforth-infographic-july-web_fullsize.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"422\" data-original-width=\"750\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-ZFJVO9rRbAc/XJy543zqECI/AAAAAAABgYk/dF8Yj0OJsyk3kxJG062UVuGTBUnIcT9fwCLcBGAs/s1600/dddanforth-infographic-july-web_fullsize.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The beneficial bacteria\ncolonize the soil and reside in the small rock pores and structures within the\nsoil.&nbsp; Once the microbes form colonies,\nthen they will become part of the overall microbiology profile in the soil.&nbsp;&nbsp; The microbes excel at mineralizing nutrients\nfrom rock forms into plant usable forms</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Would a drought affect\nor kill the microbes?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Far from it, the\nmicrobes will continue to multiply exponentially. And remain living in both\nlayers of soil. At the time of drought, it provides support to plants and\nrhizosphere with their hormones and water retention capacity. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The bacteria will start multiplying which\nbreaks down organic matter and transforms it into organic acids. The acids then\nstart to combine with various matter in the soil including salt. This is known\nas chelating.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Chelation is when a coating is formed around\nmatter such as salt or metals. This coating allows plants to absorb more\nnutrients from it while taking in less salt. As the bacteria continues to\nmultiply and chelate, water starts to penetrate deeper which causes salt to\nmove downward.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This chain reaction allows water to reach deeper in the soil\nwhile also removing salt from topsoil and moving it deeper into the ground\ngiving your plants access to more nutrients..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Roots serve many\nfunctions for a plant including anchorage and acquisition of vital nutrients\nand water necessary for growth. The plant root-soil interface is a dynamic\nregion in which numerous biogeochemical processes take place driven by the\nphysical activity, and the diversity of chemicals released by the plant root\nand mediated by soil microorganisms.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In turn the processes occurring in this\nregion control a host of reactions regulating terrestrial carbon and other\nelement cycling that sustain plant growth and which have an enormous influence\non plant and microbial community function and structure which greatly influence\na variety of ecosystem level processes<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are two broad\ncategories of mycorrhizal associations with plant roots, ectomycorrhiza and\nendomycorrhiza, which are differentiated by how they physically interface with\nthe plant<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;
