font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In ectomycorrhizal\nassociation, the fungus forms a mantle or sheath over the surface of fine\nlateral roots of the host trees and sends some hyphae into the intercellular\nspaces of the outer cortex forming a so-called Hartignet. Arbuscules and\nvesicles, characteristically present in endomycorrhizae are absent. The lateral\nroots covered by the fungal mantle often assume a swollen or coralloid form.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ectomycorrhizal fungi\nis of great importance in afforestation. In developing pine forests, it is\nalways ensured that the seedlings are inoculated with soil containing the\nappropriate strains of ectomyct rrhizal fungi. Trees with ectomycorrhizal\nassociation are capable of growing better under nutrient-deficient conditions\nin comparison to non-mycorrhizal plants, because of their greater ability to\nabsorb nutrients from soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Endomycorrhizal\nassociations are more common than the ecto-mycorrhizal ones and they are found\nin almost all groups of higher plants. The best known endo-mycorrhizae are\nthose of orchids. It is well- known that under natural conditions, orchids are\nunable to grow without association with fungi.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The endomycorrhizal\nfungi enter into the root cells and are generally restricted to the cortical\nregion rarely crossing the endodermis. The vesicular-arbuscular types form\ncharacteristic structures within the cells. After growing for some time in the\ncells, these structures degenerate and eventually decompose, thereby providing\nnutrition to the host. Thus, in VAM the plant host is directly benefited.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic fertilizers do\nnot contain nutrient-salt complexes but are loaded with organic material that\nslowly releases for season long nutrient absorption by crops.&nbsp; The conversion of the organic fertilizer into\nplant usable nutrients is facilitated by microorganisms.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microbes are the only species on earth that\ncan convert nutrients in the soil into forms that plants can use.&nbsp; No other chemicals or mechanisms are able to\nperform the functions of beneficial bacteria.&nbsp;\nThis is the reason why organic fertilizers and beneficial bacteria are\nessential to soil health and crop production.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteria are able to\ntake carbon atoms from organic compounds and convert them into organic acid\nchains.&nbsp; This means that they can take\nthe carbon atoms from CO2 and link them together into organic acids that plants\ncan benefit from in the soil. The bacteria decrease CO2 during carbon cycling\nand sequestration.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are thousands of\ndifferent types of bacteria, that can both help and harm people.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Only 5% of what is\nproduced by green plants is consumed by animals, but the 95% is consumed by\nmicroorganisms. One gram of fertile soil can contain up to one billion\nbacteria.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are many different types of bacteria, and most of them have not\neven been discovered yet! Most of these bacteria are aerobic, meaning that they\nrequire oxygen from the soil atmosphere. However, other bacteria need to live\nwithout oxygen, and other types can live both with, and without oxygen.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\ngrowth of these bacteria is limited by the food that is available in the soil<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fungi and bacteria\nprovide the foundation for soil biological ecosystems, and estimates of their\npopulation and structure appear to provide an accurate measure of ecosystem\nhealth and productivity..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Proper balance between\nthe two groups of microbes is key, with fungal domination of the microbial\ncommunity most healthful for soils. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pant growth is poorly\ncorrelated with soil levels of nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and organic\nmatter. On the other hand, he found a good correlation between plant growth and\nfungal-bacteria ratios in fungal-dominated soils.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Both fungi and bacteria\nderive their energy requirements directly from plants \u2013 as exudates from plant\nroots \u2013 or indirectly through consumption of plant-originated organic matter<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Up to 10 billion\nbacterial cells inhabit each gram of soil in and around plant roots, a region\nknown as the rhizosphere<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microbes can make\nnutrients and minerals in the soil available to plants, produce hormones that\nspur growth, stimulate the plant immune system and trigger<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Healthy soil can\nincrease fertility in multiple ways, including supplying nutrients such as\nnitrogen and protecting against pests and disease, <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The group of bacteria\ncalled rhizobia live inside the roots of legumes and fix nitrogen from the air\ninto a biologically<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These microbes interact\nclosely with each other, forming complex networks. They communicate with\nchemical signals. They work together to break down complex organic materials,\nincluding dead plants and animals.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">They often work in teams to complete\nbiochemical processes, such as transforming nitrogen from an inert gas to\nplant-usable forms, and recycling it from dead plant materials back into\ndissolved forms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rhizobia are\ndiazotrophic bacteria that fix nitrogen after becoming established inside the\nroot nodules of legumes (Fabaceae). To express genes for nitrogen fixation,\nrhizobia require a plant host; they cannot independently fix nitrogen. In\ngeneral, they are gram negative, motile, non-sporulating rods.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rhizobium organisms in\nthe soil recognize and invade the root hairs of their specific plant host,\nenter the plant tissues, and form a root nodule. This process causes the\nbacteria to lose many of their free-living characteristics.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">They become\ndependent upon the carbon supplied by the plant, and, in exchange for carbon,\nthey convert nitrogen gas to ammonia, which is used by the plant for its\nprotein synthesis and growth. In addition, many bacteria can convert nitrate to\namines for purposes of synthesizing cellular materials or to ammonia when\nnitrate is used as electron acceptor.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Denitrifying bacteria convert nitrate to\ndinitrogen gas. The conversion of ammonia or organic amines to nitrate is\naccomplished by the combined activities of the aerobic organisms Nitrosomonas\nand Nitrobacter, which use ammonia as an electron donor.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the carbon cycle,\ncarbon dioxide is converted into cellular materials by plants and autotrophic\nprokaryotes, and organic carbon is returned to the atmosphere by heterotrophic\nlife-forms. The major breakdown product of microbial decomposition is carbon\ndioxide, which is formed by respiring aerobic organisms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some micro-organisms\nare able to metabolise organic matter and release ammonium in a process called\nmineralisation. Others take free ammonium and oxidise it to nitrate.\nNitrogen-fixing bacteria are capable of metabolising N2 into the form of\nammonia in a process called nitrogen fixation.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrate may also be lost from\nthe soil when bacteria metabolise it to the gases N2 and N2O. The loss of\ngaseous forms of nitrogen to the atmosphere due to microbial action is called\ndenitrification. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the process of\nmineralisation, microbes feed on organic matter, releasing ammonia (NH3),\nammonium (NH4+) and other nutrients.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again, a long as the carbon to nitrogen ratio\n(C/N) of fresh residues in the soil is above 30:1, nitrogen will be in short\nsupply and other bacteria will feed on the ammonium and incorporate its\nnitrogen into their cells in the immobilization process.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In that form the\nnitrogen is said to be immobilised. Later, when such bacteria die, they too are\nmineralised and some of the nitrogen is released as ammonium and nitrate. If\nthe C/N is less than 15, ammonia is freed to the soil, where it may be used by\nbacteria which oxidise it to nitrate (nitrification).</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At any given time, 95\nto 99 percent of the potentially available nitrogen in the soil is in organic\nforms, either in plant and animal residues, in the relatively stable soil\norganic matter, or in living soil organisms, mainly microbes such as bacteria.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This nitrogen is not directly available to plants, but some can be converted to\navailable forms by microorganisms. A very small amount of organic nitrogen may\nexist in soluble organic compounds, such as urea, that may be slightly\navailable to plants.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">.Soil C results both\ndirectly from growth and death of plant roots, as well as indirectly from the\ntransfer of carbon-enriched compounds from roots to soil microbes<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Actinomycetes are soil microorganisms like both bacteria and fungi, and have\ncharacteristics linking them to both groups. They are often believed to be the\nmissing evolutionary link between bacteria and fungi, but they have many more\ncharacteristics in common with bacteria than they do fungi. Actinomycetes give\nsoil its characteristic smell. They have also been the source of several\nsignificant therapeutic medicines.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Actinomycetes are soil\nmicroorganisms. They are a type of bacteria, but they share some\ncharacteristics with fungi&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fungi are abundant in\nsoil, but bacteria are more abundant. Fungi are important in the soil as food\nsources for other, larger organisms, pathogens, beneficial symbiotic\nrelationships with plants or other organisms and soil health.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fungi can be\nsplit into species based primarily on the size, shape and color of their\nreproductive spores, which are used to reproduce. Most of the environmental\nfactors that influence the growth and distribution of bacteria and\nactinomycetes also influence fungi.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The quality as well as quantity of organic\nmatter in the soil has a direct correlation to the growth of fungi, because\nmost fungi consume organic matter for nutrition. Fungi thrive in acidic\nenvironments, while bacteria and actinomycetes cannot survive in acid, which\nresults in an abundance of fungi in SLIGHTLY acidic areas.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Fungi also grow well in dry, arid soils because fungi are aerobic, or dependent\non oxygen, and the higher the moisture content in the soil, the less oxygen is\npresent for them. Most fungi grow well at slight acidic pH values however at pH\nbelow 2 or above 8 it can not grow.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogen is important\nto all living things, including us. It plays a key role in plant growth: too\nlittle nitrogen and plants cannot thrive, leading to low crop yields; but too\nmuch nitrogen can be toxic to plants..</span>&nbsp;T<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">he nitrogen cycle is a\nrepeating cycle of processes during which nitrogen moves through both living\nand non-living things: the atmosphere, soil, water, plants, animals and\nbacteria.&nbsp; &nbsp;Microscopic living organisms that usually contain only one cell and are\nfound everywhere.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteria can cause decomposition or breaking down, of organic\nmaterial in soils.. In order to move through the different parts of the cycle,\nnitrogen must change forms. In the atmosphere, nitrogen exists as a gas (N2),\nbut in the soils it exists as nitrogen oxide, NO, and nitrogen dioxide, NO2..</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Efficient\nuse of N by meeting crop needs while avoiding excessive applications of N is an\nimportant goal.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-FHmQGBM7RJU/XJyshG_6m1I/AAAAAAABgX8/a048yQ_NY4kyXTMkrvI0ckAjeo1oZqQdgCLcBGAs/s1600/fcvvigure-3.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"518\" data-original-width=\"765\" height=\"432\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-FHmQGBM7RJU/XJyshG_6m1I/AAAAAAABgX8/a048yQ_NY4kyXTMkrvI0ckAjeo1oZqQdgCLcBGAs/s640/fcvvigure-3.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are five stages\nin the nitrogen cycle-- fixation or volatilization, mineralization,\nnitrification, immobilization, and denitrification.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fixation refers to the\nconversion of atmospheric N&nbsp; to a plant\navailable form.&nbsp;&nbsp; Nitrogen fixation\nrequires energy, enzymes and minerals, so&nbsp;\nif a plant available form of N is present, the crop will&nbsp; use it instead of fixing it from the air.</span>&nbsp;</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When\nlegumes are tilled into the soil, the N&nbsp; stored\nin their roots is released and made&nbsp; available\nto the next crop or lost to the&nbsp; environment,\ndepending on management.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mineralization is the\nprocess by which microbes&nbsp; decompose\norganic N from manure, organic matter&nbsp; and\ncrop residues to ammonium. Because it is a biological process, rates of\nmineralization vary with soil temperature, moisture and the amount of oxygen in\nthe soil (aeration).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrification is the\nprocess by which&nbsp; microorganisms convert\nammonium to nitrate to obtain energy. Nitrate is the most plant available form\nof N, but is also highly susceptible to leaching losses.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Denitrification occurs\nwhen N is lost through the conversion of nitrate to gaseous forms of N, such as\nnitric oxide, nitrous oxide and dinitrogen gas. This&nbsp; occurs when the soil is saturated and the\nbacteria use nitrate as an oxygen source&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Volatilization is the loss of N through\nthe conversion of ammonium to ammonia gas, which is released to the atmosphere.\nThe volatilization losses&nbsp; increase at\nhigher soil pH and conditions that favor evaporation (e.g. hot and windy).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Immobilization is the\nreverse of mineralization. All&nbsp; living\nthings require N; therefore microorganisms in&nbsp;\nthe soil compete with crops for N. Immobilization&nbsp; refers to the process in which nitrate and&nbsp; ammonium are taken up by soil organisms and therefore\nbecome unavailable to crops.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Leaching is a pathway\nof N loss of a high concern&nbsp; to water\nquality. Soil particles do not retain nitrate&nbsp;\nvery well because both are negatively charged. As a&nbsp; result, nitrate easily moves with water in\nthe soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The rate of leaching\ndepends on soil drainage,&nbsp; rainfall,\namount of nitrate present in the soil, and crop uptake..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Crop Uptake is the\nprime goal of N management&nbsp; on farms. The\ngreatest efficiency occurs when adequate N is applied at a time when the crop\nis actively taking it up. Efficient N use also depends on a number of other\nfactors including temperature,&nbsp; soil\nmoisture, pest pressure, and soil compaction\u2026<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ultimate goal of N\nmanagement is to&nbsp; maximize N efficiency\nby increasing crop uptake and&nbsp; minimizing\nN losses to the environment. Crop N&nbsp; needs\ncan be met through existing N sources (e.g.&nbsp;\nfrom soil organic matter, past sods and previously&nbsp; applied manure)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil organic matter\nexists as decomposing plant and animal residues, relatively stable products of\ndecomposition-resistant compounds and humus. Nitrogen has accumulated in these\nvarious organic fractions during soil development.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic matter\nformation and stability is largely related to long-term moisture and\ntemperature trends. With higher average temperatures, soil organic matter\ndecreases. As moisture increases, soil organic matter increases. Higher\ntemperatures lead to more rapid and complete organic matter decomposition to\nsoluble products which can leach from soil. Increasing moisture causes more\nplant growth, resulting in more organic residue.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plants normally use\nnitrogen in only the ammonium and nitrate forms. Nitrite is actually toxic to\nplants.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The nitrogen cycle, as\ntypically described, begins with nitrogen in its simplest stable form,\ndinitrogen (N2), and follows it through the processes of fixation,\nmineralization, nitrification, leaching, plant assimilation, ammonia\nvolatilization, denitrification, and immobilization.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fixation is the process\nof converting dinitrogen gas to chemically reactive forms \u2014 where nitrogen\ncombines with other elements such as oxygen, hydrogen, and carbon. These forms\nare dependent on fixation.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lightning fixes nitrogen into various oxides that\nrain and snow deposit. Typically, this is less than 10 pounds of total nitrogen\nper acre per year. Bacteria can convert nitrogen to organic forms through\nfixation. Fixation can occur either in free-living organisms or symbiotically\nin association with legumes. Nitrogen is also fixed industrially through\nseveral processes.</span>&nbsp;</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once nitrogen is fixed, it is subject to\nseveral chemical reactions which can convert it to different organic or\ninorganic forms. Mineralization occurs in soil as microorganisms convert\norganic nitrogen to inorganic forms. The first step of mineralization is called\naminization, in which microorganisms (primarily heterotrophs) break down\ncomplex proteins to simpler amino acids, amides, and amines.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-5oGteqZ35D8/XJy41W_yf6I/AAAAAAABgYU/vEcbLpyY7VU_s5Mr5EWJDsREpeIr5FoiACLcBGAs/s1600/decoccmposition%252Bby%252Bbacteria%252B%2526%252Bfungi.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"720\" data-original-width=\"960\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-5oGteqZ35D8/XJy41W_yf6I/AAAAAAABgYU/vEcbLpyY7VU_s5Mr5EWJDsREpeIr5FoiACLcBGAs/s640/decoccmposition%252Bby%252Bbacteria%252B%2526%252Bfungi.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Saturating soils with a\nready supply of nitrate can cause denitrification \u2014 the conversion of nitrate\nto various gaseous forms of nitrogen which can be lost to the atmosphere\n(nitric oxide, nitrous oxide, dinitrogen). Denitrification occurs under\noxygen-limiting conditions when anaerobic bacteria use nitrate in respiration\nin the presence of carbon sources such as organic matter.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Denitrifying bacteria,\nmicroorganisms whose action results in the conversion of nitrates in soil to\nfree atmospheric nitrogen, thus depleting soil fertility and reducing\nagricultural productivity.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dentrifying bacteria\nare a diverse group of bacteria that encompass many different phyla. This group\nof bacteria, together with dentrifying fungi and archaea, is capable of\nperforming denitrification as part of the nitrogen cycle They metabolise\nnitrogenous compounds using various enzymes, turning nitrogen oxides back to\nnitrogen gas or nitrous oxide.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Without\ndenitrification, however, the Earth\u2019s supply of nitrogen would eventually\naccumulate in the oceans, since nitrates are highly soluble and are\ncontinuously leached from the soil into nearby bodies of water</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The process of\ndenitrification can lower the fertility of soil as nitrogen, a growth-limiting\nfactor, is removed from the soil and lost to the atmosphere. This loss of\nnitrogen to the atmosphere can eventually be regained via introduced nutrients,\nas part of the nitrogen cycle. Some nitrogen may also be fixated by species of\nnitrifying bacteria and the cyanobacteria.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrification will\noccur once ammonia becomes readily available in urine-contaminated soils.\nAmmonia is oxidized into nitrite and nitrate via nitrifying bacteria.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Denitrification is the\nprocess that produces the most nitrous oxide. Denitrification involves\nthe reduction of nitrites and nitrates produced during nitrification into\nnitrous oxide by denitrifying bacteria. Nitrous oxide is subsequently reduced\nto dinitrogen, the key product of the nitrogen cycle. Nitrous oxide is merely a\nfree obligatory intermediate and is not a major product.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic agriculture has\nshown decreased nitrous oxide emissions through limiting the number of cattle\npresent per hectare of pasture. A decreased number of cattle in one hectare\nleads to less nitrogenous constituents deposited into the soil at one time and\nstrains the occurrence of nitrification and denitrification. This in turn\nlimits the total amount of nitrous oxide that can be produced.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogen stabilizers\nare commonly used to protect against nitrogen losses through volatilization,\ndenitrification and leaching. Nitrification occurs when ammonium is converted\nto nitrite in the soil by nitrosomonas bacteria, and then further oxidized to\nnitrate by nitrobacter bacteria. A majority of the nitrogen taken up by the\nplant is in the nitrate form, but most plants can also take up ammonium.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Most plant nutrients,\nwith the exception of nitrogen, originate from the minerals that make up the\nsoil parent material. Some nitrogen originates from rain as dilute nitric acid\nand ammonia, but most of the nitrogen is available in soils as a result of\nnitrogen fixation by bacteria.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once in the soil-plant system, most nutrients\nare recycled through living organisms, plant and microbial residues (soil\norganic matter), mineral-bound forms, and the soil solution. Both living\nmicroorganisms and soil organic matter are of critical importance to this\nrecycling, and thereby to soil formation and soil fertility.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogenous fertilizers\ntend to create acidic conditions, which are fatal to the worms, and dead\nspecimens are often found on the surface following the application of\nsubstances</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;There is a lot of nitrogen in the atmosphere,\nbut it is not easy for plants to get. There are certain species of bacteria\nthat absorb nitrogen gas from the atmosphere, and form a nodule. These are\ncalled nitrogen fixing bacteria. When the die, the nitrogen that they used are\nreleased for plants.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteria live in almost\nany habitat. They are found inside the digestive system of animals, in the\nocean and fresh water, in compost piles (even at temperatures over 130\u00b0F), and\nin soils. Although some kinds of bacteria live in flooded soils without oxygen,\nmost require well-aerated soils. In general, bacteria tend to do better in\nneutral pH soils than in acid soils.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In addition to being\namong the first organisms to begin decomposing residues in the soil, bacteria\nbenefit plants by increasing nutrient availability. For example, many bacteria\ndissolve phosphorus, making it more available for plants to use.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteria are\nalso very helpful in providing nitrogen to plants, which they need in large\namounts but is often deficient in agricultural soils. You may wonder how soils\ncan be deficient in nitrogen when we are surrounded by it\u201478% of the air we\nbreathe is composed of nitrogen gas.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yet plants as well as animals face a\ndilemma similar to that of the Ancient Mariner, who was adrift at sea without\nfresh water: \u201cWater, water, everywhere nor any drop to drink.\u201d Unfortunately,\nneither animals nor plants can use nitrogen gas (N2) for their nutrition.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;However, some types of bacteria are able to take nitrogen gas from the\natmosphere and convert it into a form that plants can use to make amino acids\nand proteins. This conversion process is known as nitrogen fixation.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some nitrogen-fixing\nbacteria form mutually beneficial associations with plants. One such symbiotic\nrelationship that is very important to agriculture involves the nitrogen-fixing\nrhizobia group of bacteria that live inside nodules formed on the roots of\nlegumes.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These bacteria provide nitrogen in a form that leguminous plants can\nuse, while the legume provides the bacteria with sugars for energy.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-QGX0OKA1gPA/XJy4DluReSI/AAAAAAABgYE/MNfDWPwWBkMhAP-vMJzB4v8c2J-H7uRlwCLcBGAs/s1600/E-ff2.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"454\" data-original-width=\"750\" height=\"386\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-QGX0OKA1gPA/XJy4DluReSI/AAAAAAABgYE/MNfDWPwWBkMhAP-vMJzB4v8c2J-H7uRlwCLcBGAs/s640/E-ff2.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Protozoa are\nsingle-celled animals that use a variety of means to move about in the soil.\nLike bacteria and many fungi, they can be seen only with the help of a\nmicroscope. They are mainly secondary consumers of organic materials, feeding\non bacteria, fungi, other protozoa, and organic molecules dissolved in the soil\nwater.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-EYhPQ3HkmnI/XJy5J13J0sI/AAAAAAABgYc/JEIqxwKvqOk9CL7Tl3LUJvlw6kudO59agCLcBGAs/s1600/stejlprdb1237711.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"977\" data-original-width=\"1420\" height=\"438\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-EYhPQ3HkmnI/XJy5J13J0sI/AAAAAAABgYc/JEIqxwKvqOk9CL7Tl3LUJvlw6kudO59agCLcBGAs/s640/stejlprdb1237711.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Protozoa\u2014through their grazing on nitrogen-rich organisms and excreting\nwastes\u2014are believed to be responsible for mineralizing (releasing nutrients\nfrom organic molecules) much of the nitrogen in agricultural soils.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Protozoa are\nsingle-celled animals that feed primarily on bacteria, but also eat other\nprotozoa, soluble organic matter, and sometimes fungi.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">They are several times\nlarger than bacteria. As they eat bacteria, protozoa release excess nitrogen\nthat can then be used by plants and other members of the food web.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil bacteria\nhave a carbon-to-nitrogen ratio of about 5:1 while protozoa have a ratio closer\nto 10:1.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the protozoa feed on the bacteria, they consume more nitrogen than\nthey need. The excess is excreted and utilized by plants, and the cycling process\ncontinues.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-lmetGzESrJQ/XJy4YwIQ2LI/AAAAAAABgYM/T_WfR8N7GGIWj9N3BMpgTwrVdFkMJ_uMQCLcBGAs/s1600/Soil%252BxxProtozoa.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"720\" data-original-width=\"960\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-lmetGzESrJQ/XJy4YwIQ2LI/AAAAAAABgYM/T_WfR8N7GGIWj9N3BMpgTwrVdFkMJ_uMQCLcBGAs/s640/Soil%252BxxProtozoa.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plant production and\nbiomass (living material) are limited by the availability of nitrogen.\nUnderstanding how the plant-soil nitrogen cycle works can help us make better\ndecisions about what crops to grow and where to grow them, so we have an\nadequate supply of food.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Knowledge of the nitrogen cycle can also help us\nreduce pollution caused by adding too much fertilizer to soils. Certain plants\ncan uptake more nitrogen or other nutrients, such as phosphorous, another\nfertilizer, and can even be used as a \u201cbuffer,\u201d or filter, to prevent excessive\nfertilizer from entering waterways.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Not enough nitrogen in the soils leaves\nplants hungry, while too much of a good thing can be bad: excess nitrogen can\npoison plants and even livestock! Pollution of our water sources by surplus\nnitrogen and other nutrients is a huge problem, as marine life is being\nsuffocated from decomposition of dead algae blooms.. We need to protect the\nnatural plant buffer zones that can take up nitrogen runoff before it reaches\nwater bodies..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plants respond to\nnutrient deficiency by altering root morphology, recruiting the help of\nmicroorganisms and changing the chemical environment of the rhizosphere.&nbsp; The nutrients most limiting to plant growth\nare nitrogen and phosphorus. Even though 78% of the Earth's atmosphere is\ncomposed of nitrogen (N2 gas), it is in a form that is only utilizable by\nnitrogen-fixing organisms. As such, inorganic forms of N (NO3-,NH4+) that can\nbe used by plants are added to soils.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The availability of nitrogen in most\nsoils is low because of the leaching losses of soluble nitrate (NO3-) with\ninfiltrating rainwater, fixation of ammonium (NH4+) in clays and soil organic\nmatter and bacterial denitrification. Plants respond differently depending on\nthe form of nitrogen in the soil.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ammonium has a positive charge, and thus the\nplant expels one proton (H+) for every NH4+ taken up resulting in a reduction\nin rhizosphere pH. When supplied with NO3-, the opposite can occur where the\nplant releases bicarbonate (HCO3-) which increases rhizosphere pH. These\nchanges in pH can influence the availability of other plant essential\nmicronutrients (e.g., Zn, Ca, Mg).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Symbiotic\nnitrogen-fixing bacteria, such as Rhizobium species, detect compounds like\nflavonoids secreted by the roots of leguminous plants and then produce nod\nfactors which signal to the plant that they are present and will lead to the\nformation of root nodules. In these nodules bacteria, sustained by nutrients\nfrom the plant, convert nitrogen gas to a form that can be used by the\nplant.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Non-symbiotic (or\n\"free-living\") nitrogen-fixing bacteria may reside in the rhizosphere\njust outside the roots of certain plants (including many grasses), and\nsimilarly \"fix\" nitrogen gas in the nutrient-rich plant rhizosphere.\nple, nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the rhizosphere of the rice plant exhibit\ndiurnal cycles that mimic plant behavior, and tend to supply more fixed\nnitrogen during growth stages when the plant exhibits a high demand for\nnitrogen.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteria and Archaea\nare the smallest organisms in soil apart from viruses. Bacteria and Archaea are\nprokaryotic.&nbsp; &nbsp;Bacteria and archaea are the most abundant\nmicroorganisms in the soil, and serve many important purposes, including\nnitrogen fixation<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrobacter can only\nderive its energy by turning nitrite into nitrate, which is also known as\noxidation. They are microorganisms that are important in the nitrogen cycle as\nconverters of soil ammonia to nitrates, compounds usable by plants.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Unlike\nplants, where electron transfer in photosynthesis provides the energy for\ncarbon fixation, Nitrobacter uses energy from the oxidation of nitrite ions,\nNO2\u2212, into nitrate ions, NO3\u2212, to fulfill their energy needs. Nitrobacter fix\ncarbon dioxide via the Calvin cycle for their carbon requirements..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The production of\nnitrate (NO3\u2212) by oxidation of nitrite (NO2\u2212) by nitrification the process that\nproduces the inorganic nitrogen that supplies much of the demand by marine\noxygenic, photosynthetic organisms such as phytoplankton, particularly in areas\nof upwelling.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For this reason, nitrification supplies much of the nitrogen that\nfuels planktonic primary production in the world's oceans. Nitrification is\nestimated to be the source of half of the nitrate consumed by phytoplankton\nglobally.. The oxidation of ammonia to nitrate is called nitrification and is\nan important part of the nitrogen cycle.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Nitrifiers are a diverse group of\nGram-negative bacteria that obtain energy by oxidizing inorganic nitrogen\ncompounds such as ammonia or nitrite. These bacteria are of particular interest\nto farmers who fertilize their crops with ammonium nitrogen, a form of nitrogen\nthat is retained by soils because its positive charge enables it to adhere to\nnegatively charged soil particles..&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As nitrifying bacteria oxidize nitrogen\ncompounds, they consume O2. Because of this, waters polluted with\nnitrogen-containing wastes can quickly become anaerobic.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The nitrification\nprocess requires the mediation of two distinct groups: bacteria that convert\nammonia to nitrites (Nitrosomonas, Nitrosospira, Nitrosococcus, and\nNitrosolobus) and bacteria that convert nitrites (toxic to plants) to nitrates<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogen is fixed, or\ncombined, in nature as nitric oxide by lightning and ultraviolet rays, but more\nsignificant amounts of nitrogen are fixed as ammonia, nitrites, and nitrates by\nsoil microorganisms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The genus Clostridium\nis an example of bacterial versatility because it, unlike most species, can\ngrow in the absence of oxygen, respiring anaerobically. Several species of\nPseudomonas, such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa are able to respire both\naerobically and anaerobically, using nitrate as the terminal electron acceptor<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogen fixation\nNitrogen fixation, any natural&nbsp; process\nthat causes free nitrogen (N2), which is a relatively inert gas plentiful in\nair, to combine chemically with other elements to form more-reactive nitrogen\ncompounds such as ammonia, nitrates, or nitrites.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Under ordinary conditions,\nnitrogen does not react with other elements. Yet nitrogenous compounds are\nfound in all fertile soils, in all living things, Nitrogen is also found in the\nnucleus of every living cell as one of the chemical components of DNA.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogen is fixed, or\ncombined, in nature as nitric oxide by lightning and ultraviolet rays, but more\nsignificant amounts of nitrogen are fixed as ammonia, nitrites, and nitrates by\nsoil microorganisms. More than 90 percent of all nitrogen fixation is effected\nby them.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The symbiotic nitrogen-fixing bacteria invade the root hairs of host\nplants, where they multiply and stimulate the formation of root nodules,\nenlargements of plant cells and bacteria in intimate association.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Within the\nnodules, the bacteria convert free nitrogen to ammonia, which the host plant\nutilizes for its development. Legumes work in harmony with a group of bacteria\nthat live on their roots. These bacteria take nitrogen from the air and \u201cfix\u201d\nor concentrate it in pink root nodules, adding nitrogen to the soil in a form\nthe plants can absorb.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">To get scientific about\nit, Rhizobia spp. bacteria have a symbiotic relationship with legume plant\nroots. The bacteria live in nodules in the legume roots. Plants cannot absorb\nnitrogen (N2) from the air. The bacteria convert nitrogen (N2) from the air by\nadding hydrogen to create ammonium ions (NH4+) which the plants can absorb.\nConverting the nitrogen by adding hydrogen is what is called \u201cnitrogen\nfixation\u201d in legumes.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Biological nitrogen fixation converts N2 into ammonia,\nwhich is metabolized by most organisms. Nitrogen fixation is essential to life\nbecause fixed inorganic nitrogen compounds are required for the biosynthesis of\nall nitrogen-containing organic compounds, such as amino acids and proteins,\nnucleoside triphosphates and nucleic acids.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As part of the nitrogen cycle, it\nis essential for agriculture and the manufacture of fertilizer Some\nnitrogen-fixing bacteria have symbiotic relationships with some plant groups,\nespecially legumes. Nitrogen fixation also occurs between some termites and\nfungi.It also occurs naturally in the air by means of NOx production by\nlightning.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All biological nitrogen\nfixation is effected by enzymes called nitrogenases These enzymes are\nresponsible for the reduction of nitrogen (N2) to ammonia (NH3). Nitrogenases\nare the only family of enzymes known to catalyze this reaction, which is a key\nstep in the process of nitrogen fixation.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogen fixation is required for all\nforms of life, with nitrogen being essential for the biosynthesis of molecules\n(nucleotides, amino acids) that create plants, Nitrogenase is an enzyme\nresponsible for catalyzing nitrogen fixation, which is the reduction of\nnitrogen (N2) to ammonia (NH3) and a process vital to sustaining life on Earth<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; float: left; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<img alt=\"\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-QSnd-Z8F7Kc/XFtPudWdwlI/AAAAAAABfq4/vxrkFOO7Iu8Mf6-OaPgw6FPpRDSmMgLdgCK4BGAYYCw/s35/capt%25252BajitC%25252Bvadakayil.JPG\" style=\"background: rgb(255, 255, 255); border: 1px solid rgb(238, 238, 238); box-shadow: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1) 1px 1px 5px; max-width: 36px; padding: 5px;\" /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2019/02/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_28.html?showComment=1551518597175#c4630046836699855545\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">March 2, 2019 at 2:53 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nXXX<br />\nIF CHANDRABABU NAIDU BECOMES CM OF ANDHRA HE WILL BUILD HIS CAPITAL AT AMRAVATI BEFORE 2024..<br />\n<br />\nPM MODI HIMSELF LAID THE FOUNDATION STONE ON 22ND OCT 2015 AT EDDANDARAYUNIPALEM AREA ON BANKS OF KRISHNA RIVER .<br />\n<br />\nWE ASK AJIT DOVAL / CBI TO CHECK THE BENAMI LANDS CHANDRABABU NAIDU HAS ACQUIRED SURREPTITIOUSLY AT THE HEART OF HIS NEW EARMARKED CAPITAL AMRAVATI .. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2019/02/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_28.html?showComment=1551518643052#c4375031982074918446\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">March 2, 2019 at 2:54 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nCONTINUED FROM 1-<br />\n<br />\nWE ALL SAW HOW KERALA WAS FLOODED RECENTLY DURING FEW DAYS OF EXCESSIVE RAIN. ..YOU CANT FILL LANDS MEANT TO RECEIVE FLOODWATERS.<br />\n<br />\nThe Singapore-based firm Subarna Jurong prepared the master plan for Amaravati.<br />\n<br />\nSINGAPORE IS A ILL PLANNED CITY WHO NEED TO BEG DRINKING WATER FROM MALAYSIA THOUGH IT RAINS HEAVILY IN SINGAPORE ALMOST EVERY DAY.<br />\n<br />\nWHAT IS THE NEED FOR THE CAPITAL OF A STATE TO BE A SUPERCITY AND THAT TOO BY SACRIFICING THE FOOD BOWL ..
