THE DELTA OF KRISHNA RIVER IN ANDHRA IS AMONG THE MOST FERTILE LANDS IN INDIA..<br /><br />THE KRISHNA RIVER WILL GET EXTREMELY POLLUTED IN THE LAST LEG OF ANDHRA STATE ..EVEN NOW THE SOIL IS SALINE AND DODIC ALKALINE AT THE LOWER REACHES OF THE RIVER BASIN.</span></b><br />\n<br />\nDOES ANDHRA WANT TO BE ANOTHER TAMIL NADU WHERE COASTAL AQUIFERS GET INGRESSED BY SALT WATER ?.<br />\n<br />\nTHIS RIVER IS 1300 KM LONG FLOWING THROUGH MAHARASHTRA, KARNATAKA AND TELENGANA<br />\n<br />\nWE ALL KNOW WHAT AN UNPLANNED CITY CALLED DELHI DID TO YAMUNA.<br />\n<br />\nALL THOSE WHO THINK THAT ALL THE WATER IN GANGES RIVER IS DUE TO ICE IN HIMALAYAS MELTING\u2014 PLEASE RAISE YOUR HANDS.. I SEE NO HANDS, -- I SEE, EVEN A WATCHING MONKEY DID NOT RAISE HIS HAND..<br />\n<br />\nWHOSE EGO IS THIS CONCEPT PANDERING TO? NAIDU BABY WANTS HIS STATUE EVERYWHERE ?<br />\n<br />\nEVEN TODAY KRISHNA FLOWING THROUGH ANDHRA TO SEA GETS DRY..<br />\n<br />\nPooling emerges from a separate state law called the Andhra Pradesh Capital Region Development Authority Act passed by the Assembly on December 22, 2014. This scheme doesn\u2019t offer monetary compensation for land taken. In exchange for village land taken today, it offers a developed piece of land in the future city.<br />\n<br />\nFor every fertile acre pooled, the state will return 25% of developed area in the future city: a 1,000 square-yard residential plot, and a 250 square-yard commercial plot..<br />\n<br />\nNaidu baby has already got a home in Amaravati.. Most pro-pooling farmers are Kammas, like Chief Minister Chandrababu Naidu. They are traditional voters of the ruling TDP.<br />\n<br />\nMost anti-pooling farmers are Reddys or Kapus, supporting the YSR Congress.<br />\n<br />\nCAPT AJIT VADAKAYIL DECLARES\u2014ALL THOSE WHO HAD VISION OF A BUSTLING AMARAVATI CITY WITH WHITE FOREIGNERS PLAYING GOLF LOOKING INTO A MIGHTY FLOWING KRISHNA RIVER \u2013THEY MUST BE COLLECTED TOGETHER AND <b><span style=\"color: red;\">SHOT WITH THEIR OWN SHIT</span></b><br />\n<br />\nCapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</ol>\n</div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Available nitrogen in\nthe soil is the essential nutrient for green leaves, and new roots and shoots.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteria are\nresponsible for the process of nitrogen fixation, which is the conversion of\natmospheric nitrogen into nitrogen-containing compounds (such as ammonia) that\ncan be used by plants. Autotrophic bacteria derive their energy by making their\nown food through oxidation, like the Nitrobacters species, rather than feeding\non plants or other organisms.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These bacteria are responsible for nitrogen\nfixation. The amount of autotrophic bacteria is small compared to heterotrophic\nbacteria (the opposite of autotrophic bacteria, heterotrophic bacteria acquire\nenergy by consuming plants or other microorganisms), but are very important\nbecause almost every plant and organism requires nitrogen in some way.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In nitrogen fixation,\nrhizobium bacteria convert N2 to ammonia (NH3). Rhizobia share a symbiotic\nrelationship with host plants, since rhizobia supply the host with nitrogen and\nthe host provides rhizobia with nutrients and a safe environment.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rhizobia are\ndiazotrophic bacteria that fix nitrogen after becoming established inside the\nroot nodules of legumes (Fabaceae). To express genes for nitrogen fixation,\nrhizobia require a plant host; they cannot independently fix nitrogen. &nbsp;In general, they are gram negative, motile,\nnon-sporulating rods.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogen is a critical\nlimiting element for plant growth and production. It is a major component of\nchlorophyll, the most important pigment needed for photosynthesis, as well as\namino acids, the key building blocks of proteins. It is acids. Even though it\nis one of the most abundant elements (predominately in the form of nitrogen gas\n(N2) in the Earth\u2019s atmosphere), plants can only utilize reduced forms of this\nelement.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plants acquire these forms of \u201ccombined\u201d nitrogen by: 1) the addition\nof ammonia and/or nitrate fertilizer (from the Haber-Bosch process) or manure\nto soil, 2) the release of these compounds during organic matter decomposition,\n3) the conversion of atmospheric nitrogen into the compounds by natural\nprocesses, such as lightning, and 4) biological nitrogen fixation <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Biological nitrogen\nfixation (BNF), discovered by Beijerinck in 1901 (Beijerinck 1901), is carried\nout by a specialized group of prokaryotes. These organisms utilize the enzyme\nnitrogenase to catalyze the conversion of atmospheric nitrogen (N2) to ammonia\n(NH3). Plants can readily assimilate NH3 to produce the aforementioned\nnitrogenous biomolecules.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These prokaryotes include aquatic organisms, such as\ncyanobacteria, free-living soil bacteria, such as Azotobacter, bacteria that\nform associative relationships with plants, such as Azospirillum, and most\nimportantly, bacteria, such as Rhizobium and Bradyrhizobium, that form\nsymbioses with legumes and other plants (Pos<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many heterotrophic\nbacteria live in the soil and fix significant levels of nitrogen without the\ndirect interaction with other organisms. Examples of this type of\nnitrogen-fixing bacteria include species of Azotobacter, Bacillus, Clostridium,\nand Klebsiella. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These organisms must\nfind their own source of energy, typically by oxidizing organic molecules\nreleased by other organisms or from decomposition. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many microorganisms fix\nnitrogen symbiotically by partnering with a host plant.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The plant provides\nsugars from photosynthesis that are utilized by the nitrogen-fixing\nmicroorganism for the energy it needs for nitrogen fixation. In exchange for\nthese carbon sources, the microbe provides fixed nitrogen to the host plant for\nits growth.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Rhizobium or\nBradyrhizobium bacteria colonize the host plant\u2019s root system and cause the\nroots to form nodules to house the bacteria . The bacteria then begin to fix\nthe nitrogen required by the plant. Access to the fixed nitrogen allows the\nplant to produce leaves fortified with nitrogen that can be recycled throughout\nthe plant. This allows the plant to increase photosynthetic capacity, which in\nturn yields nitrogen-rich seed.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ammonium ions (NH4+)\nnot immobilized or taken up quickly by higher plants are usually converted\nrapidly to NO3- ions by a process called nitrification. This is a two-step\nprocess, during which bacteria called Nitrosomonas convert NH4+ to nitrite\n(NO2-), and then other bacteria, Nitrobacter, convert the NO2- to NO3-. This\nprocess requires a well-aerated soil and occurs rapidly enough that one usually\nfinds mostly NO3- rather than NH4+ in soils during the growing season.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When bacteria feed on\nsoluble forms of nitrogen (ammonium and nitrate), they temporarily sequester\nthat nitrogen in their bodies in a process called immobilisation. At a later\ntime when those bacteria die, their nitrogen may be released as ammonium by the\nprocesses of mineralisation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Usable nitrogen may be\nlost from soils when it is in the form of nitrate, as it is easily leached.\nFurther losses of nitrogen occur by denitrification, the process whereby soil\nbacteria convert nitrate (NO3\u2212) to nitrogen gas, N2 or N2O.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This occurs when\npoor soil aeration limits free oxygen, forcing bacteria to use the oxygen in\nnitrate for their respiratory process. Denitrification increases when\noxidisable organic material is available and when soils are warm and slightly\nacidic. Denitrification may vary throughout a soil as the aeration varies from\nplace to place.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Denitrification may cause the loss of 10 to 20 percent of the available\nnitrates within a day and when conditions are favourable to that process,\nlosses of up to 60 percent of nitrate applied as fertiliser may occur.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Waterlogging causes\noxygen starvation in the root zone, which retards root development and may lead\nto death directly, or to poor growth and low productivity due to a stunted root\nsystem. Waterlogging also causes nitrogen loss through denitrification and can\naffect the availability of other nutrients. Toxins secreted by anaerobic\nbacteria, which flourish in waterlogged soils, may also damage plants.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ratio of carbon to\nnitrogen will differ from species to species, and depending upon the age of the\nplant. The ratio is referred to as C:N. The value of N is always one, whereas\nthe value of carbon or carbohydrates is expressed in a value of about 10 up to\n90; the ratio must be less than 30:1 to prevent the manure bacteria from\ndepleting existing nitrogen in the soil. Rhizobium are soil organisms that\ninteract with green manure to retain atmospheric nitrogen in the soil.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteria are organisms\nthat have only one cell and are, therefore, microscopic. There are anywhere\nfrom 100 million to one billion bacteria in just a teaspoon of moist, fertile\nsoil. They are decomposers, eating dead plant material and organic waste.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By\ndoing this, the bacteria release nutrients that other organisms could not\naccess. The bacteria do this by changing the nutrients from inaccessible to\nusable forms. The process is essential in the nitrogen cycle.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: x-large; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>WHAT IS CROP ROTATION?</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">IF WE NEED TO KICK THE\nDESH DROHI GREEN REVOLUTION AND REVERT BACK TO ORGANIC AGRICULTURE FARMERS NEED\nTO BE TAUGHT CROP ROTATION BY WAY OF TV AND FIELD CLASSES BY VOLUNTEERS TO\nASSESS THE SOIL HISTORY AND HELP ON THE SPOT.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">INDIANS TAUGHT CROP\nROTATION TO THE REST OF THE PLANET IN ANCIENT TIMES.. TODAY WE ARE STRUGGLING\nWITH THE GREEN REVOLUTION GIFTS GIVEN TO US BY DESH DROHI MS SWAMINATHAN.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">WE ASK THE MODI GOVT TO\nCERTIFY FARMERS WHO DO NOT USE ARTIFICIAL FERTILIZERS AND PESTICIDES..THESE\nFARMERS MUST BE GIVEN A HEFTY INCENTIVE.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">VIDEOS MUST BE TAKEN TO PROVE\nEARTHWORMS EXIST .. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">SEALED SOIL SAMPLES\nMUST BE TAKEN BY CERTIFIED TECHNICIANS TO THE LAB AND ANALYSED FOR MICROBES..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/11/sampling-procedures-chemical-tankers.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/11/sampling-procedures-chemical-tankers.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Crop rotation is the\npractice of growing a series of dissimilar or different types of crops in the\nsame area in sequenced seasons. It is done so that the soil of farms is not\nused for only one set of nutrients.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It helps in reducing soil erosion and\nincreases soil fertility and crop yield. Growing the same crop in the same\nplace for many years in a row (monocropping) disproportionately depletes the\nsoil of certain nutrients.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">With rotation, a crop that leaches the soil of one\nkind of nutrient is followed during the next growing season by a dissimilar\ncrop that returns that nutrient to the soil or draws a different ratio of\nnutrients.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In addition, crop rotation mitigates the buildup of pathogens and\npests that often occurs when one species is continuously cropped, and can also\nimprove soil structure and fertility by increasing biomass from varied root\nstructures.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A preliminary assessment of crop interrelationships can be found in\nhow each crop:---</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;(1) contributes to soil organic matter (SOM) content, (2)\nprovides for pest management, (3) manages deficient or excess nutrients, and\n(4) how it contributes to or controls for soil erosion..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Crop rotation allows\nthe land to regenerate and rejuvenate its self-nutrients without having to\napply more nutrients through the use of fertilizers.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Crop choice is often\nrelated to the goal the farmer is looking to achieve with the rotation, which\ncould be weed management, increasing available nitrogen in the soil,\ncontrolling for erosion, or increasing soil structure and biomass, to name a\nfew..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Crop rotation must\nconsider in what condition one crop will leave the soil for the succeeding crop\nand how one crop can be seeded with another crop. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For example, a nitrogen-fixing crop, like a\nlegume, should always precede a nitrogen depleting one; similarly, a low\nresidue crop (i.e. a crop with low biomass) should be offset with a high\nbiomass cover crop, like a mixture of grasses and legumes..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Intercropping is a\nmultiple cropping practice involving growing two or more crops in proximity.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The most common goal of intercropping is to produce a greater yield on a given\npiece of land by making use of resources or ecological processes that would\notherwise not be utilized by a single crop.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Multiple cropping is\nthe practice of growing two or more crops in the same piece of land in same\ngrowing seasons instead of one crop. It is a form of polyculture.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It can take\nthe form of double-cropping, in which a second crop is planted after the first\nhas been harvested, or relay cropping, in which the second crop is started\namidst the first crop before it has been harvested.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The use of different\nspecies in rotation allows for increased soil organic matter (SOM), greater\nsoil structure, and improvement of the chemical and biological soil environment\nfor crops. With more SOM, water infiltration and retention improves, providing\nincreased drought tolerance and decreased erosion.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil organic matter is\na mix of decaying material from biomass with active microorganisms. Crop\nrotation, by nature, increases exposure to biomass from sod, green manure, and\na various other plant debris.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The reduced need for intensive tillage under crop\nrotation allows biomass aggregation to lead to greater nutrient retention and\nutilization, decreasing the need for added nutrients. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microorganisms are what make nutrients\navailable to plants. So, where \"active\" soil organic matter is a key\nto productive soil, soil with low microbial activity provides significantly\nfewer nutrients to plants; this is true even though the quantity of biomass\nleft in the soil may be the same.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil microorganisms\nalso decrease pathogen and pest activity through competition. In addition,\nplants produce root exudates and other chemicals which manipulate their soil\nenvironment as well as their weed environment.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus rotation allows increased\nyields from nutrient availability but also alleviation of allelopathy and\ncompetitive weed environments. Similar plants tend to have the same pathogens,\ntherefore, crop rotation intercepts the pest life cycle and their habitat.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Crop rotations greatly\nincrease soil organic carbon (SOC) content, the main constituent of soil\norganic matter. Carbon, along with hydrogen and oxygen, is a macronutrient for\nplants. Highly diverse rotations spanning long periods of time have shown to be\neven more effective in increasing SOC, while soil disturbances (e.g. from\ntillage) are responsible for exponential decline in SOC levels..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rotating crops adds\nnutrients to the soil. Legumes, plants of the family Fabaceae, for instance,\nhave nodules on their roots which contain nitrogen-fixing bacteria called rhizobia.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During a process called nodulation, the rhizobia bacteria use nutrients and\nwater provided by the plant to convert atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia, which\nis then converted into an organic compound that the plant can use as its\nnitrogen source&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;It therefore makes good sense agriculturally\nto alternate them with cereals (family Poaceae) and other plants that require\nnitrates. How much nitrogen made available to the plants depends on factors\nsuch as the kind of legume, the effectiveness of rhizobia bacteria, soil\nconditions, and the availability of elements necessary for plant food<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Crop rotation is used\nto control pests and diseases that can become established in the soil over\ntime. The changing of crops in a sequence decreases the population level of\npests by:--</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;(1) interrupting pest life cycles and (2) interrupting pest habitat. Plants\nwithin the same taxonomic family tend to have similar pests and pathogens.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By\nregularly changing crops and keeping the soil occupied by cover crops instead of\nlying fallow, pest cycles can be broken or limited, especially cycles that\nbenefit from overwintering in residue<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Integrating certain\ncrops, especially cover crops, into crop rotations is of particular value to\nweed management.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These crops crowd out weed through competition. In addition,\nthe sod and compost from cover crops and green manure slows the growth of what\nweeds are still able to make it through the soil, giving the crops further\ncompetitive advantage.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By removing slowing the growth and proliferation of\nweeds while cover crops are cultivated, farmers greatly reduce the presence of\nweeds for future crops, including shallow rooted and row crops, which are less\nresistant to weeds. Cover crops are, therefore, considered conservation crops\nbecause they protect otherwise fallow land from becoming overrun with weeds..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Crop rotation\ncontributes to increased yields through improved soil nutrition. By requiring\nplanting and harvesting of different crops at different times, more land can be\nfarmed with the same amount of machinery and labour.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For example, say a\nfarmer has planted a field of corn. When the corn harvest is finished, he might\nplant beans, since corn consumes a lot of nitrogen and beans return nitrogen to\nthe soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If a farmer plants the\nexact same crop in the same place every year, as is common in conventional\nfarming, she continually draws the same nutrients out of the soil. Pests and\ndiseases happily make themselves a permanent home as their preferred food\nsource is guaranteed. With monocultures like these, increasing levels of\nchemical fertilizers and pesticides become necessary to keep yields high while\nkeeping bugs and disease at bay.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Crop rotation increases\nsoil fertility by controlling deficient or excess nutrients because it\nreplenishes nutrients that are not available or absorbing nutrients that are in\nabundance. It also increases the soil organic matter caused by the\nmicro-organisms left behind by each type of crop planted.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Animals that also\ngraze on land left to fallow contribute to adding manure to the ground that\nfertilizes the soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Crop rotation helps\nreturn nutrients to the soil without synthetic inputs.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic crops perform\nbetter in weak-acidic to weak-alkaline soils\u2014soils with pH between 5.5 and 8.0.\nThis happens because of the difficulty in managing phosphorus in organic\nsystems. Under strong alkaline and acidic conditions, phosphorus is less\nreadily available to plants as it forms insoluble phosphates.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Crop rotation helps\nprevent soil compaction thus improving the physical condition of the soil. This\nallows for good condition for seed germination and root proliferation. It also\nhelps with other soil processes such as water infiltration and aeration, which\nhave a lot of benefits to the crops and improves the composition of the soil.</span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/0IJX1rCgSYg/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/0IJX1rCgSYg?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cover crops take carbon\nout of the atmosphere as they grow and funnel it into the soil. Unlike cash\ncrops that are harvested and removed from the soil, cover crops are left to\ndecompose and contribute to soil formation.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A cover crop is planted to manage\nsoil erosion, soil fertility, soil quality, water, weeds, pests, diseases,\nbiodiversity and wildlife in an agroecosystem\u2014an ecological system managed and\nshaped by humans.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cover crops may be an off-season crop planted after\nharvesting the cash crop. The cover crop may grow over winter. One of the primary\nuses of cover crops is to increase soil fertility. These types of cover crops\nare referred to as \"green manure.\" They are used to manage a range of\nsoil macronutrients and micronutrients.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Of the various nutrients, the impact\nthat cover crops have on nitrogen management has received the most attention\nfrom researchers and farmers, because nitrogen is often the most limiting\nnutrient in crop production.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Often, green manure\ncrops are grown for a specific period, and then plowed under before reaching\nfull maturity in order to improve soil fertility and quality. Also the stalks\nleft block the soil from being eroded.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A cover crop is a crop\nof a specific plant that is grown primarily for the benefit of the soil rather\nthan the crop yield. Cover crops are commonly used to suppress weeds, manage\nsoil erosion, help build and improve soil fertility and quality, control\ndiseases and pests, and promote biodiversity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cover crops are\ntypically grasses or legumes but may be comprised of other green plants. And,\nmost often, a cover crop is grown in the off-season before the field is needed\nfor growing the cash crop. In essence, a cover crop readies the land for an\nincoming cash crop.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cover crops reduce the amount of water that drains off a\nfield, protecting waterways and downstream ecosystems from erosion. Because\neach root of the cover crop creates pores in the soil, cover crops help allow\nwater to filter deep into the ground. As a result, a cover crop can help\nconserve water and prevent soil erosion.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cover crops can help\nbreak disease cycles by reducing the amount of bacterial and fungal diseases in\nthe soil. If you have a soil that is infested, you can plant a cover crop in\nthat area as a means to eradicate the disease.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cover crops are sometimes called\n\"green manure\" because they provide nutrients to the soil, much like\nmanure does. They are also called \"living mulches\" because they can\nprevent soil erosion. A mulch is a layer of organic material, such as crop\nresidue, that is left on the surface of the soil to prevent water runoff and\nprotect the soil from the damaging effects of heavy rainfall.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cover crops are\nan important part of sustainable agriculture. These crops add fertility to the\nsoil without chemical fertilizers via biological nitrogen fixation. A cover\ncrop can offer a natural way to reduce soil compaction, manage soil moisture,\nreduce overall energy use, and provide additional forage for livestock.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Small farmers choose to\ngrow specific cover crops based on their needs and goals and the overall\nrequirements of the land they are working. Cover crops grown in summer are\noften used to fill in space during crop rotations, help amend the soil, or\nsuppress weeds. Winter cover crops help hold soil in place over the winter ..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This ensures that the\nsoil has a suitable energy reserve as well as tissue building material to\nenable the plants to thrive.</span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In a fish tank, a\nfish\u2019s primary waste is ammonia. Ammonia is produced by the breakdown of\nprotein, the main staple of most fishes\u2019 diets. Ammonia is excreted out through\nthe urinary tract and gills. Ammonia is highly toxic to fish, causing death and\nincreased secondary illness, so it is converted, through nitrogen-fixing\nbacteria, into nitrite. Now, nitrite can be just as bad as ammonia.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Methemoglobinemia, or \u201cBrown Blood Disease,\u201d\nis caused by a build-up of nitrite. Nitrite can bind to hemoglobin in the blood\nand outcompete oxygen. This causes a brown coloration and the fish will\nasphyxiate from lack of oxygen.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thankfully, more nitrogen-fixing bacteria\nconvert nitrite into the final nitrate. Nitrate is safe for fish at low levels,\nbut at higher levels, and depending on the fish species\u2019 tolerance, can cause\nthe same issues as high ammonia. Nitrate is removed from the system by aquatic\nplants or water changes.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microorganisms are very\nsmall forms of life that can sometimes live as single cells, although many also\nform colonies of cells. A microscope is usually needed to see individual cells\nof these organisms. Many more microorganisms exist in topsoil, where food\nsources are plentiful, than in subsoil.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">They are especially abundant in the\narea immediately next to plant roots (called the rhizosphere), where\nsloughed-off cells and chemicals released by roots provide ready food sources.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These organisms are primary decomposers of organic matter, but they do other\nthings, such as provide nitrogen through fixation to help growing plants, detoxify\nharmful chemicals (toxins), suppress disease organisms, and produce products\nthat might stimulate plant growth.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Soil microorganisms have had another direct\nimportance for humans\u2014they are the source of most of the antibiotic medicines\nwe use to fight diseases.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil is a wonderful\nsource of bacteria that can make new antibiotics.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One teaspoon of healthy\nsoil contains hundreds of millions&nbsp; of\nbacteria.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">ANCIENT AYURVEDA NOT\nONLY USED GOLD ( FROM HUMPED COW URINE ) AND SILVER COLLOIDS ( FROM GANGES\nHEAD RIVER WATERS ) AS ANTIBIOTICS BUT ALSO SOIL BACTERIA FROM SNAKE\nGROVES.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">HERBS COLLECTED FROM SNAKE\nGROVES ARE CONSUMED WITHOUT WASHING OR LIGHT RINSING ...<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">EVERY SNAKE GROVE HAD A\nPOND WITH FISHES INSIDE.&nbsp; EVEN SWALLOWING\nTHE FISHES WITHOUT COOKING CURED DISEASES.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">WHY IS GANGES RIVER\nWATER HOLY?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">BECAUSE IT IS THE ONLY\nRIVER ON THE PLANET CONTAINING BACTERIOPHAGES.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Before the Suez canal\nwas built,&nbsp; British East India company\nships would stock up Ganges water from the fag end of Ganges river&nbsp; off Calcutta.&nbsp;\nThis water would hold excellent quality till the ship arrived at London,\nand sailors would be in the pink of health .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On the reverse passage\nthey would stock fresh water from river Thames and this water would develop\nfungus , have bacteria and stink, and the water had to be discarded and\nreplenished enroute .&nbsp; Sailors used to he\nhalf dead by the time the ship reached India.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A quarter century ago,\nI had an argument with a Dutch river pilot .&nbsp;\nWhen I pointed out some white chemical ( Styrene ) foam in water river water\nand a dead sea gull&nbsp; , he ridiculed the\nholy river Ganges .&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">I instantly busted his\nbubble by telling him that the Ganges which flows from the mythical hairlocks\nof Lord Shiva is self cleansing due to the action of bacteriophages ,&nbsp; silver/ himalayan salt colloids&nbsp; and hyper oxygenation\u2014and it is the only\nriver on the planet which has this ability.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteriophage, is a\nvirus,&nbsp; any of a group of viruses that\ninfect bacteria\u2014it literally means&nbsp;\n\u201cbacteria eater\u201d . <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br />\n<b style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">BELOW:&nbsp; BACTERIOPHAGES OF THE GANGES RIVER HAVE INNATE INTELLIGENCE AND THEY DO ONLY GOOD TO HUMANS.&nbsp; &nbsp;THIS IS WHY WE CALL GANGES A HOLY RIVER WITH LIVING WATER ..</span></b><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/mT8OsGxVUsw/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/mT8OsGxVUsw?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thousands of varieties\nof such phages exist, each of which may infect only one type or a few types of\nbacteria..&nbsp; The nucleic acid may be\neither DNA or RNA and may be double-stranded or single-stranded.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During infection a\nphage attaches to a bacterium and inserts its genetic material into the\ncell.&nbsp; After this a phage follows one of\ntwo life cycles, lytic (virulent) or lysogenic (temperate).&nbsp; Lytic phages take over the machinery of the\ncell to make phage components.&nbsp; They then\ndestroy, or lyse, the cell, releasing new phage particles.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">After the discovery of\nantibiotics in the 1940s it was virtually abandoned.&nbsp; With the ever increasing rise of anti-biotic\nresistant bacteria , phages will now command fresh attention.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">More than 125 years ago\nthere was a cholera outbreak in India and dead bodies were dumped in the upper\nriver. Yet strangely Ganges water did NOT spread the cholera down the river . <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A British\nbacteriologist by the name of Dr Ernest Hankin found that colonies of cholera\nbacteria that thrived in ground water quickly died in Ganges water.&nbsp; He pursued his experiment by using boiled\nGanges water and filtered Ganges water. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">To his surprise, while\nthe filtered water ( which could not hold back nano colloids ) continued to\nshow an antibacterial effect, the boiled water did not.&nbsp; Heating water flocculates ( agglomerates )\nand sediments the magic colloids and also kills the magic bacteriophages.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/FZQjf3zmxM0/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/FZQjf3zmxM0?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ganges is heavily\npopulated with phages which multiply rapidly , travel fast and home in on\ntargets . They are harmless to humans because they are strain specific.&nbsp; This means phages that infect the cholera\nbacterium can only infect the cholera bacterium and no other bacteria.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2011/01/living-water-capt-ajit-vadakayil.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2011/01/living-water-capt-ajit-vadakayil.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When a bacteriophage\nfinds a bacterium with proteins which match its receptors, it can insert DNA or\nRNA into the bacterium and direct the organism to start producing replicas of\nthe virus.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the process of\nreplicating the bacteriophage, many bacteria will experience lysis, in which\nthey literally explode as they become overloaded with viruses.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Unlike antibiotics,\nphages take out the pathogen without harming the natural flora and friendly\nbacteria present in the body .&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: blue; font-size: large;\">The EVIL PHARMA has killed all efforts to\nrevive phage research.&nbsp; Bacteriophages which\nare viruses infect and kill their host bacteria by a magical SEARCH AND DESTROY\naction. </span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Phages have been\nkeeping keeping bacteria in check for three and a half billion years!\nAntibiotics have been around for a few decades are they are already failing to\ndo their job.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">60 years ago people\nwould put a few drops of Ganga water into ponds and it would kill all the\nbacterial growth.&nbsp;&nbsp; Even today the\npolluted Ganga that kills pathogens twenty-five times faster than any other\nriver. But with the onslaught of toxic chemicals from tanneries this rate has\nslowed down.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dams have prevented the\nphages from doing their job. There are phages for all bacteria. A cholera phage\ncan only attach to a cholera bacteria, an E. coli phage only to that specific\nE. coli and so on. They simply bide their time until they can sense that\nbacteria .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A phage or virus is a\nkind of macromolecule. It cannot replicate itself in nature. It has to\npenetrate the body of a suitable host and use its mechanism to replicate.&nbsp; It can hang around in shady waters for years,\nbut you won\u2019t notice it because there is no host. It will only express itself\nwhen there is a bacterial host. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Without a host in sight\nit just remains dormant. The phage that will kill cholera will not kill\nshigella dysentery even though they are both diarrhoeal diseases. And one that\nkills shigella will not kill typhoid, and so on.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;The bacteria which phages feed on can come\nfrom human bodies when they bathe. The human body in water in fact acts as a\ncatalyst.&nbsp; The higher the concentration\nof bathers the more food for the phages to feast on.&nbsp; So wherever there are major bathing festivals\nlike the Kumbh mela,phages will flock.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Having found out its\nprey, the phage will multiply and the whole area suddenly becomes rich in\nphages. &nbsp;So a few days after a Kumbh Mela\nthe riversuddenly acquired greater powers of self-purification.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Now you get the drift\nwhy Capt Ajit Vadakayil got pissed off with the ignoramus river pilot in\nNetherlands.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteriophages can\neliminate the bacteria in the water. Compared to antibiotics, bacreriophages go\ndeeper into the infected area. The replication of phages is concentrated on the\ninfected area where they are needed the most. <o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; Antibiotics are metabolized and removed from\nthe body, with associated side effects.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Himalayas were\npushed up when two continents collided .&nbsp;\nThis is why Tibet is elevated and Mount Everest is the tallest mountain\npeak , which is still rising.&nbsp;&nbsp; AS <span style=\"color: red;\">KOSHER CUNTS </span>LIKE JACK DORSEY, MARK ZUCKERBERG AND ANGELO D ADAMS THINK</b><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;
