The\naggregates are relatively stable oil pores are the spaces between soil\nparticles and between soil aggregates. They can be full of air or they can have\nwater in them.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-7B9wEwflRME/XJ-3nOpGDqI/AAAAAAABgaw/NsKCuhx-ZWUFXitEtfVDpvAHRavCjvqIwCLcBGAs/s1600/Soil%252Baggregates%252Bare%252Bformed%252Band%252Bstabilized%252Bby%252Bclayd-organic%252Bcomplexes%252C%252Bmicrobial%252Bpolysaccharides%252C%252Bfungal%252Bhyphae%252Band%252Bplant%252Broots..jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"720\" data-original-width=\"960\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-7B9wEwflRME/XJ-3nOpGDqI/AAAAAAABgaw/NsKCuhx-ZWUFXitEtfVDpvAHRavCjvqIwCLcBGAs/s640/Soil%252Baggregates%252Bare%252Bformed%252Band%252Bstabilized%252Bby%252Bclayd-organic%252Bcomplexes%252C%252Bmicrobial%252Bpolysaccharides%252C%252Bfungal%252Bhyphae%252Band%252Bplant%252Broots..jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A polysaccharide is an organic compound composed of many simple\ncarbon compounds, identical to each other, joined together in a long chain.\nThey are released into the soil by microorganisms and roots. Polysaccharides\nare long and flexible and they can make points of contact with many soil\nparticles. In this way they have been associated with the formation of\naggregates in soil.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Firstly, bacteria produce polysaccharides which can make\nmany points of contact with soil particles producing aggregates. Unlike the\npolysaccharides produced by plant roots, bacterial polysaccharides resist\ndecomposition long enough to be involved in holding soil particles together in\naggregates.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Secondly, bacteria develop a small electrostatic charge which\nattracts to the electrostatic charge on clay surfaces, bringing together small\naggregates of soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water is essential to\nplants for four reasons:--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It constitutes 80%-95%\nof the plant's protoplasm.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is essential for\nphotosynthesis.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is the solvent in\nwhich nutrients are carried to, into and throughout the plant.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It provides the\nturgidity by which the plant keeps itself in proper position.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil bulk density is\nequal to the dry mass of the soil divided by the volume of the soil; i.e., it\nincludes air space and organic materials of the soil volume. Thereby soil bulk\ndensity is always less than soil particle density and is a good indicator of\nsoil compaction<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water moves in soil\nunder the influence of gravity, osmosis and capillarity.When water enters the\nsoil, it displaces air from interconnected macropores by buoyancy, and breaks\naggregates into which air is entrapped, a process called slaking.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The rate at which a\nsoil can absorb water depends on the soil and its other conditions. As a plant\ngrows, its roots remove water from the largest pores (macropores) first. Soon\nthe larger pores hold only air, and the remaining water is found only in the\nintermediate- and smallest-sized pores (micropores).&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-007QZMLIwVk/XJ-3MC78xyI/AAAAAAABgao/oglFLm8nljUmcUjh2pX2fVX74bBAcBGAACLcBGAs/s1600/dodwnload.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"194\" data-original-width=\"259\" height=\"299\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-007QZMLIwVk/XJ-3MC78xyI/AAAAAAABgao/oglFLm8nljUmcUjh2pX2fVX74bBAcBGAACLcBGAs/s400/dodwnload.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The water in the smallest\npores is so strongly held to particle surfaces that plant roots cannot pull it\naway. Consequently, not all soil water is available to plants, with a strong\ndependence on texture.When saturated, the soil may lose nutrients as the water\ndrains.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water moves in a draining field under the influence of pressure where\nthe soil is locally saturated and by capillarity pull to drier parts of the\nsoil.&nbsp; Most plant water needs are\nsupplied from the suction caused by evaporation from plant leaves\n(transpiration) and a lower fraction is supplied by suction created by osmotic\npressure differences between the plant interior and the soil solution.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-lD9YYdFkQ1Q/XJ-27gt9eAI/AAAAAAABgag/PHus8QZTJOY1_kYVetRnchGI5m11isWpQCLcBGAs/s1600/rdownload.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"191\" data-original-width=\"265\" height=\"286\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-lD9YYdFkQ1Q/XJ-27gt9eAI/AAAAAAABgag/PHus8QZTJOY1_kYVetRnchGI5m11isWpQCLcBGAs/s400/rdownload.png\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plant roots must seek out water and grow\npreferentially in moister soil microsites, but some parts of the root system\nare also able to remoisten dry parts of the soil. Insufficient water will\ndamage the yield of a crop.&nbsp; Most of the\navailable water is used in transpiration to pull nutrients into the plant.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Water is retained in a\nsoil when the adhesive force of attraction that water's hydrogen atoms have for\nthe oxygen of soil particles is stronger than the cohesive forces that water's\nhydrogen feels for other water oxygen atoms.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">When a field is flooded, the soil pore space is completely filled by\nwater. The field will drain under the force of gravity until it reaches what is\ncalled field capacity, at which point the smallest pores are filled with water\nand the largest with water and gases.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The total amount of water held when field\ncapacity is reached is a function of the specific surface area of the soil\nparticles.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">As a result, high clay and\nhigh organic soils have higher field capacities.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The total force required to pull or push\nwater out of soil is termed suction and usually expressed in units of bars</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">which is just a little less than\none-atmosphere pressure. Alternatively, the terms \"soil moisture\ntension\" or water potential may be used.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water potential is the\npotential energy of water per unit volume relative to pure water in reference\nconditions. Water potential quantifies the tendency of water to move from one\narea to another due to osmosis, gravity, mechanical pressure, or matrix effects\nsuch as capillary action (which is caused by surface tension).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If flow is not\nrestricted, water will move from an area of higher water potential to an area\nthat is lower potential.&nbsp; With no\nrestriction on flow, water will move from the locus of greater potential (pure\nwater) to the locus of lesser (the solution); flow proceeds until the\ndifference in potential is equalized or balanced by another water potential\nfactor, such as pressure or elevation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A soil solution&nbsp; experiences osmotic potential. The osmotic\npotential is made possible due to the presence of both inorganic and organic\nsolutes in the soil solution. As water molecules increasingly clump around\nsolute ions or molecules, the freedom of movement, and thus the potential\nenergy, of the water is lowered.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-9Vf-m9ZyT6A/XJ-2Y2oqcFI/AAAAAAABgaY/E2GfNl4dTiYPSexJax3GRbvDfIkAuJitgCLcBGAs/s1600/xr9.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"403\" data-original-width=\"456\" height=\"564\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-9Vf-m9ZyT6A/XJ-2Y2oqcFI/AAAAAAABgaY/E2GfNl4dTiYPSexJax3GRbvDfIkAuJitgCLcBGAs/s640/xr9.png\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the concentration of solutes is increased,\nthe osmotic potential of the soil solution is reduced. Since water has a\ntendency to move toward lower energy levels, water will want to travel toward\nthe zone of higher solute concentrations. Although, liquid water will only move\nin response to such differences in osmotic potential if a semipermeable\nmembrane exists between the zones of high and low osmotic potential.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A\nsemipermeable membrane is necessary because it allows water through its\nmembrane while preventing solutes from moving through its membrane. If no membrane\nis present, movement of the solute, rather than of the water, largely equalizes\nconcentrations.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Since regions of soil\nare usually not divided by a semipermeable membrane, the osmotic potential\ntypically has a negligible influence on the mass movement of water in soils. On\nthe other hand, osmotic potential has an extreme influence on the rate of water\nuptake by plants.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If soils are high in soluble salts, the osmotic potential is\nlikely to be lower in the soil solution than in the plant root cells. In such\ncases, the soil solution would severely restrict the rate of water uptake by\nplants. In salty soils, the osmotic potential of soil water may be so low that\nthe cells in young seedlings start to collapse (plasmolyze).<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-6C_XOZ99Vkg/XJ-2CwC1JzI/AAAAAAABgaQ/e7r_NHDwrMsQmTVTne2bmpoBAxR5t-FVgCLcBGAs/s1600/sdownload.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"141\" data-original-width=\"358\" height=\"252\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-6C_XOZ99Vkg/XJ-2CwC1JzI/AAAAAAABgaQ/e7r_NHDwrMsQmTVTne2bmpoBAxR5t-FVgCLcBGAs/s640/sdownload.png\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When water is in\ncontact with solid particles (e.g., clay or sand particles within soil),\nadhesive intermolecular forces between the water and the solid can be large and\nimportant. The forces between the water molecules and the solid particles in\ncombination with attraction among water molecules promote surface tension and\nthe formation of menisci within the solid matrix.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Force is then required to\nbreak these menisci. The magnitude of matrix potential depends on the distances\nbetween solid particles\u2014the width of the menisci (also capillary action and\ndiffering Pa at ends of capillary)\u2014and the chemical composition of the solid\nmatrix (meniscus, macroscopic motion due to ionic attraction).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-TDcBhev_bNg/XJ-1etAPxlI/AAAAAAABgaA/CtgKvEDjtMw1oyQjAu4giRu1JxtpMJVhQCLcBGAs/s1600/The%252BMatric%252BPotential%252ByT%252B%253D%252Bysz%252B%252B%252Bym%252B%252B%252Byp%252B%252B%252Bys%252B%252B.....jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"720\" data-original-width=\"960\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-TDcBhev_bNg/XJ-1etAPxlI/AAAAAAABgaA/CtgKvEDjtMw1oyQjAu4giRu1JxtpMJVhQCLcBGAs/s640/The%252BMatric%252BPotential%252ByT%252B%253D%252Bysz%252B%252B%252Bym%252B%252B%252Byp%252B%252B%252Bys%252B%252B.....jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The matrix potential is\nalways negative because the water attracted by the soil matrix has an energy\nstate lower than that of pure water. Matrix potential only occurs in\nunsaturated soil above the water table. If the matrix potential approaches a\nvalue of zero, nearly all soil pores are completely filled with water, i.e.\nfully saturated and at maximum retentive capacity.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-r4x1zaTpyFY/XJ-1srnsphI/AAAAAAABgaE/zQgTueDJhdYjAaKV6jdfRTFvsq-L4eHCwCLcBGAs/s1600/soil-water-plant-rexlationships-34-638.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"479\" data-original-width=\"638\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-r4x1zaTpyFY/XJ-1srnsphI/AAAAAAABgaE/zQgTueDJhdYjAaKV6jdfRTFvsq-L4eHCwCLcBGAs/s640/soil-water-plant-rexlationships-34-638.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The matrix potential can\nvary considerably among soils. In the case that water drains into less-moist\nsoil zones of similar porosity, the matrix potential is generally in the range\nof \u221210 to \u221230 kPa.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: blue; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\">1 Atmos= 760mm HG=\n29.92 inch HG= 33.899 feet FW= 1.033 kg/cm2=&nbsp;\n14.69 psi= 1.0133 bars= 101.3 kPa (KN m2)= 1013.3 HPa (mb)</span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: blue; font-size: large;\">1 kpa= 102 mm aq,&nbsp;&nbsp; 1 kg= 100 kpa,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1 mpa= 10 kg.</span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/vmo0FRAVgkM/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/vmo0FRAVgkM?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/10/soil-liquefaction-during-earth-quakes.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/10/soil-liquefaction-during-earth-quakes.html</a></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-aI2ITFerKWs/XKC7C9IOjPI/AAAAAAABgcw/vAo7x5eZIeQYykVMpe-0ktUs6szVcc32QCLcBGAs/s1600/gimages.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/N_Ycd0cttjc/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/N_Ycd0cttjc?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: x-large;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">CRYING BOLLYWOOD SUPERSTAR\u2014&nbsp; SANS BASIC UNDERSTANDING OF </span><b><span style=\"color: red;\">DARCYs LAW</span></b><span style=\"color: blue;\"> !!</span></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: lime;\"><a href=\"https://sandrp.in/2018/04/30/drp-news-bulletin-30-april-2018-paani-foundation-expands-to-4000-villages-in-maharashtra/\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">https://sandrp.in/2018/04/30/drp-news-bulletin-30-april-2018-paani-foundation-expands-to-4000-villages-in-maharashtra/</a><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">IN USA AND EUROPE VAPOR RETURN CALCULATION\nWERE WRONG\u2026<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">SOME CUNT STARTED A MINDLESS METHOD AND ALL\nWERE FOLLOWING THAT TILL BAAD BOY VADAKAYIL STOPPED IT QUOTING DARCYs LAW..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">CALCULATIONS IN THIS POST WILL MAKE ALL IIT\nPROFESSORS SCRATCH THEIR BOTTOM ORIFICES AND SMELL IT FOR GOOD MEASURE ..&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: cyan;\">MIND YOU , WE ARE DEALING WITH HIGHLY TOXIC ,\nAND CARCINOGENIC GASES.. THERE IS NO ROOM FOR ERROR.</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/12/vapor-return-system-chemical-tankers.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/12/vapor-return-system-chemical-tankers.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/aAZzpz7udgk/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/aAZzpz7udgk?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>WE ASK THE MODI GOVT\nNOT TO ALLOW PUBLICITY KA BHOOKA BOLLYWOOD SUPERSTARS AND CONMEN LIKE SRI SRI\nRAVISHANKAR AND SADGURU JAGGI VASUDEV TO DABBLE IN HYDROGEOLOGY ..&nbsp;&nbsp;</b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">THIS IS A COMPLICATED MATER FOR THE BRIGHTEST\nMINDS OF INDIA..</b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2014/05/interlinking-rivers-of-india-capt-ajit.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2014/05/interlinking-rivers-of-india-capt-ajit.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Darcy's law is an\nequation that describes the flow of a fluid through a porous medium. The law\nwas formulated by Henry Darcy based on the results of experiments &nbsp;on the flow of water through beds of sand, forming\nthe basis of hydrogeology.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-g02SfDgSvnw/XKDIVUtd8mI/AAAAAAABgdQ/9TEWR2EXB28m7rdLIEIzVmzd3g8iXWKawCLcBGAs/s1600/ground-Swater-hydrology-80-638.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"479\" data-original-width=\"638\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-g02SfDgSvnw/XKDIVUtd8mI/AAAAAAABgdQ/9TEWR2EXB28m7rdLIEIzVmzd3g8iXWKawCLcBGAs/s640/ground-Swater-hydrology-80-638.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-jEFBCIVMsjE/XKDJsZ1iAOI/AAAAAAABgdY/77F0cFntLGs-FBcw-UXvzjoCYG8uYJfpwCLcBGAs/s1600/Darcy%25E2%2580%2599s%252BLawE%252BDarcy%25E2%2580%2599s%252Blaw%252Bprovides%252Ban%252Baccurate%252Bdescription%252Bof%252Bthe%252Bflow%252Bof%252Bground%252Bwater%252Bin%252Balmost%252Ball%252Bhydrogeologic%252Benvironments..jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"720\" data-original-width=\"960\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-jEFBCIVMsjE/XKDJsZ1iAOI/AAAAAAABgdY/77F0cFntLGs-FBcw-UXvzjoCYG8uYJfpwCLcBGAs/s640/Darcy%25E2%2580%2599s%252BLawE%252BDarcy%25E2%2580%2599s%252Blaw%252Bprovides%252Ban%252Baccurate%252Bdescription%252Bof%252Bthe%252Bflow%252Bof%252Bground%252Bwater%252Bin%252Balmost%252Ball%252Bhydrogeologic%252Benvironments..jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b>AT SEA, CAPT AJIT\nVADAKAYIL IS KNOWN AS THE \"UNIVERSAL WATER SEEKING YOUR LEVEL\"<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b>I DONT REVEAL MY THINKING PROCESSES .&nbsp; &nbsp;LUMP IT OR LEAVE IT ..</b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b>YOU GET TO SEE IT NOW , BECAUSE THIS POST IS FOR HCD ( NO LCD&nbsp; -- LOWEST COMMON DENOMINATOR DIMWITS )&nbsp;</b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/11/old-sea-dog-capt-ajit-vadakayil.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/11/old-sea-dog-capt-ajit-vadakayil.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/mb8clQdvrvo/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/mb8clQdvrvo?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil is made up of\nsmall particles, providing lots of surfaces that will bind water. This binding\nis highly dependent on soil type. For example, sandy soil has large particles\nwhich provide less surface binding sites, while a silt loam has smaller\nparticles and more surface binding sites.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Matric potential is\nalways negative or zero, and is the most significant component of soil water\npotential in unsaturated conditions.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Matric potential arises\nbecause water is attracted to most surfaces through hydrogen bonding and van\nder Waals forces. This water droplet is pure but no longer free. The matric\nforces that bind it to the plastic have lowered its potential and you would\nhave to use some energy to remove it from the surface and take it to a pool of\npure, free water.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Osmotic potential\ndescribes the dilution and binding of water by solutes that are dissolved in\nthe water. This potential is also always negative.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Osmotic potential only\naffects the system if there is a semi-permeable barrier that blocks the passage\nof solutes. This is actually quite common in nature. For example, plant roots\nallow water to pass but block most solutes. Cell membranes also form a\nsemi-permeable barrier.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A less obvious example is the air-water interface,\nwhere water can pass into air in the vapor phase, but salts are left behind.\nGravitational potential arises because of water\u2019s location in a gravitational\nfield.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It can be positive or negative depending on where you are in relation to\nthe specified reference of pure, free water at the soil surface Pressure\npotential is a hydrostatic or pneumatic pressure being applied to or pulled on\nthe water.&nbsp; It is a more macroscopic\neffect acting throughout a larger region of the system.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are several\nexamples of positive pressure potential in the natural environment.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For example, there is a\npositive pressure present below the surface of any groundwater. You can feel\nthis pressure yourself as you swim down into a lake or pool. Similarly, a\npressure head or positive pressure potential develops as you move below the\nwater table.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Though pressure potential is usually positive, there are important\ncases where it is not. One is found in plants, where a negative pressure\npotential in the xylem draws water from the soil up through the roots and into\nthe leaves.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Ph-7tQuIbz4/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Ph-7tQuIbz4?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/qv91V_qkUHk/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/qv91V_qkUHk?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-l3Niz9nnpCY/XKDRR7DDI7I/AAAAAAABgdg/3oKqi-oDmm4PaHqePvF-HdMjDy2F7xeSACLcBGAs/s1600/img_5b58gdc57e5f5e.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"302\" data-original-width=\"416\" height=\"464\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-l3Niz9nnpCY/XKDRR7DDI7I/AAAAAAABgdg/3oKqi-oDmm4PaHqePvF-HdMjDy2F7xeSACLcBGAs/s640/img_5b58gdc57e5f5e.png\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-rAcGBPFZi8M/XKDRhHuJh5I/AAAAAAABgdk/91NASJ-cLHcKh-xMTzS_2fTZhMLL-ejawCLcBGAs/s1600/Water%252BPotential%252C%252B%25CE%25A8%252BWatfer%252Bpotential%252Bof%252Bthe%252Bsoil%252Bis%252Bnegative%252C%252Bbut%252Bnot%252Bas%252Bnegative%252Bas%252Bthe%252Bcell%252C%252Bdue%252Bto%252Bthe%252Bhigh%252Bcontent%252Bof%252Bsolutes..jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"720\" data-original-width=\"960\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-rAcGBPFZi8M/XKDRhHuJh5I/AAAAAAABgdk/91NASJ-cLHcKh-xMTzS_2fTZhMLL-ejawCLcBGAs/s640/Water%252BPotential%252C%252B%25CE%25A8%252BWatfer%252Bpotential%252Bof%252Bthe%252Bsoil%252Bis%252Bnegative%252C%252Bbut%252Bnot%252Bas%252Bnegative%252Bas%252Bthe%252Bcell%252C%252Bdue%252Bto%252Bthe%252Bhigh%252Bcontent%252Bof%252Bsolutes..jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At a potential of 0\nkPa, soil is in a state of saturation. At saturation, all soil pores are filled\nwith water, and water typically drains from large pores by gravity. At a\npotential of \u221233 kPa, or \u22121/3 bar, (\u221210 kPa for sand), soil is at field capacity.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Typically, at field capacity, air is in the macropores and water in micropores.\nField capacity is viewed as the optimal condition for plant growth and\nmicrobial activity. At a potential of \u22121500 kPa, soil is at its permanent\nwilting point, meaning that soil water is held by solid particles as a\n\"water film\" that is retained too tightly to be taken up by plants.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In contrast,\natmospheric water potentials are much more negative\u2014a typical value for dry air\nis \u2212100 MPa, though this value depends on the temperature and the humidity.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-O5ZmJHcXON0/XKDRyd_95vI/AAAAAAABgdw/CvIBfg2tnPk4WZtN0Ek0K_0zm1ou3Nq-QCLcBGAs/s1600/movement-of-water-from-root-tof-atmosphere-3-638.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"479\" data-original-width=\"638\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-O5ZmJHcXON0/XKDRyd_95vI/AAAAAAABgdw/CvIBfg2tnPk4WZtN0Ek0K_0zm1ou3Nq-QCLcBGAs/s640/movement-of-water-from-root-tof-atmosphere-3-638.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Root water potential\nmust be more negative than the soil, and the stem water potential and\nintermediate lower value than the roots but higher than the leaf water\npotential, to create a passive flow of water from the soil to the roots, up the\nstem, to the leaves and then into the atmosphere.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The forces with which\nwater is held in soils determine its availability to plants. Forces of adhesion\nhold water strongly to mineral and humus surfaces and less strongly to itself\nby cohesive forces. A plant's root may penetrate a very small volume of water\nthat is adhering to soil and be initially able to draw in water that is only\nlightly held by the cohesive forces.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">But as the droplet is drawn down, the\nforces of adhesion of the water for the soil particles produce increasingly\nhigher suction, finally up to 15 bar.At 15 bar suction, the soil water amount\nis called wilting point.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;At that suction the plant cannot sustain its water\nneeds as water is still being lost from the plant by transpiration, the plant's\nturgidity is lost, and it wilts, although stomatal closure may decrease\ntranspiration and thus may retard wilting below the wilting point, in\nparticular under adaptation or acclimatization to drought.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The next level,\ncalled air-dry, occurs at 1000 bar suction. Finally the oven dry condition is\nreached at 10,000 bar suction. All water below wilting percentage is called\nunavailable water.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/HLIAWXvVLi8/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/HLIAWXvVLi8?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the soil moisture\ncontent is optimal for plant growth, the water in the large and intermediate\nsize pores can move about in the soil and be easily used by plants. The amount\nof water remaining in a soil drained to field capacity and the amount that is\navailable are functions of the soil type. Sandy soil will retain very little\nwater, while clay will hold the maximum amount.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water moves through\nsoil due to the force of gravity, osmosis and capillarity. At zero to one-third\nbar suction, water is pushed through soil from the point of its application\nunder the force of gravity and the pressure gradient created by the pressure of\nthe water; this is called saturated flow. At higher suction, water movement is\npulled by capillarity from wetter toward drier soil. This is caused by water's\nadhesion to soil solids, and is called unsaturated flow.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/ego2FkuQwxc/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/ego2FkuQwxc?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Warm soils take in\nwater faster.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Water flows through the\nground unevenly, in the form of so-called \"gravity fingers\", because\nof the surface tension between water particles.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tree roots, whether\nliving or dead, create preferential channels for rainwater flow through soil,\nmagnifying infiltration rates of water up to 28 times.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Flooding temporarily\nincreases soil permeability in river beds, helping to recharge aquifers.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water applied to a soil\nis pushed by pressure gradients from the point of its application where it is\nsaturated locally, to less saturated areas, such as the vadose zone.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The vadose\nzone, also termed the unsaturated zone, is the part of Earth between the land\nsurface and the top of the phreatic zone, the position at which the groundwater\n(the water in the soil's pores) is at atmospheric pressure . Hence, the vadose\nzone extends from the top of the ground surface to the water table.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water in\nthe vadose zone has a pressure head less than atmospheric pressure, and is\nretained by a combination of adhesion (funiculary groundwater), and capillary\naction (capillary groundwater). If the vadose zone envelops soil, the water\ncontained therein is termed soil moisture.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In fine grained soils, capillary\naction can cause the pores of the soil to be fully saturated above the water\ntable at a pressure less than atmospheric. The vadose zone does not include the\narea that is still saturated above the water table, often referred to as the\ncapillary fringe.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once soil is completely\nwetted, any more water will move downward, or percolate out of the range of\nplant roots, carrying with it clay, humus, nutrients, primarily cations, and\nvarious contaminants, including pesticides, pollutants, viruses and bacteria,\npotentially causing groundwater contamination.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil physics\n(Darcy-type model) predicts that at suctions less than one-third bar, water\nmoves theoretically in all directions via unsaturated flow at a rate that is\ndependent on the square of the diameter of the water-filled pores.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Preferential\nflow occurs along interconnected macropores, crevices, root and worm channels,\nwhich drain water under gravity. Water is also pulled by capillary action due\nto the adhesion force of water to the soil solids, producing a suction gradient\nfrom wet towards drier soil and from macropores to micropores.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water flow (also\ncalled hydraulic conductivity) is primarily from coarse-textured soil into\nfine-textured soil horizons and is slowest in fine-textured soils such as clay.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Groundwater recharge,\nwhich is an important process that refills aquifers, generally occurs through\nthe vadose zone from precipitation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-tRJkYir167k/XKEaU01w3UI/AAAAAAABgeA/4tb3T5RkKREO7wA3jgpNa8tWP3Cm6FvkQCLcBGAs/s1600/250Spx-Vadose_zone.gif\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"190\" data-original-width=\"250\" height=\"304\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-tRJkYir167k/XKEaU01w3UI/AAAAAAABgeA/4tb3T5RkKREO7wA3jgpNa8tWP3Cm6FvkQCLcBGAs/s400/250Spx-Vadose_zone.gif\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Of equal importance to\nthe storage and movement of water in soil is the means by which plants acquire\nit and their nutrients. Most soil water is taken up by plants as passive\nabsorption caused by the pulling force of water evaporating (transpiring) from\nthe long column of water (xylem sap flow) that leads from the plant's roots to\nits leaves, according to the cohesion-tension theory. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The upward movement of water and solutes\n(hydraulic lift) is regulated in the roots by the endodermis &nbsp;and in the plant foliage by stomatal\nconductance, and can be interrupted in root and shoot xylem vessels by cavitation,\nalso called xylem embolism. &nbsp;In addition,\nthe high concentration of salts within plant roots creates an osmotic pressure\ngradient that pushes soil water into the roots. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Osmotic absorption becomes more important\nduring times of low water transpiration caused by lower temperatures (for\nexample at night) or high humidity, and the reverse occurs under high\ntemperature or low humidity. It is these process that cause guttation and wilting,\nrespectively.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Root extension is vital\nfor plant survival. &nbsp;Root architecture,\ni.e. the spatial configuration of the root system, plays a prominent role in\nthe adaptation of plants to soil water and nutrient availabiity, and thus in\nplant productivity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Roots must seek out\nwater as the unsaturated flow of water in soil can move only at a rate of up to\none inch per day; as a result they are constantly dying and growing as they\nseek out high concentrations of soil moisture. &nbsp;Insufficient soil moisture, to the point of\ncausing wilting, will cause permanent damage and crop yields will suffer.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Only a small fraction\n(0.1% to 1%) of the water used by a plant is held within the plant. The majority\nis ultimately lost via transpiration, while evaporation from the soil surface\nis also substantial, the transpiration : evaporation ratio varying according to\nvegetation type and climate, peaking in tropical rainforests and dipping in\nsteppes and deserts.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Transpiration plus evaporative soil moisture loss is\ncalled evapotranspiration. Evapotranspiration plus water held in the plant\ntotals to consumptive use, which is nearly identical to evapotranspiration.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Evaporation accounts\nfor the movement of water to the air from sources such as the soil, canopy\ninterception, and waterbodies. Transpiration accounts for the movement of water\nwithin a plant and the subsequent loss of water as vapor through stomata in its\nleaves. Evapotranspiration is an important part of the water cycle.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Evapotranspiration is a significant water loss from drainage basins. Types of\nvegetation and land use significantly affect evapotranspiration, and therefore\nthe amount of water leaving a drainage basin. Because water transpired through\nleaves comes from the roots, plants with deep reaching roots can more\nconstantly transpire water.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Factors that affect evapotranspiration include the\nplant's growth stage or level of maturity, percentage of soil cover, solar\nradiation, humidity, temperature, and wind.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Through\nevapotranspiration, forests reduce water yield, except in unique ecosystems\ncalled cloud forests. Trees in cloud forests collect the liquid water in fog or\nlow clouds onto their surface, which drips down to the ground. These trees still\ncontribute to evapotranspiration, but often collect more water than they\nevaporate or transpire.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Potential\nevapotranspiration is higher in the summer, on less cloudy days, and closer to\nthe equator, because of the higher levels of solar radiation that provides the\nenergy for evaporation. Potential evapotranspiration is also higher on windy\ndays because the evaporated moisture can be quickly moved from the ground or\nplant surface, allowing more evaporation to fill its place.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/HmEyymGXOfI/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/HmEyymGXOfI?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil pH is a measure of\nthe acidity or basicity (alkalinity) of a soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/04/ph-for-chemical-tankerman-capt-ajit.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/04/ph-for-chemical-tankerman-capt-ajit.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/04/deionised-or-demineralised-water.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/04/deionised-or-demineralised-water.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/11/ph-chemical-tankers-capt-ajit-vadakayil.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/11/ph-chemical-tankers-capt-ajit-vadakayil.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The optimum pH range\nfor most plants is between 5.5 and 7.5<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many processes\ncontribute to soil acidification.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These include:--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rainfall: Acid soils\nare most often found in areas of high rainfall. Rainwater has a slightly acidic\npH (usually about 5.7) due to a reaction with CO2 in the atmosphere that forms\ncarbonic acid. When this water flows through soil it results in the leaching of\nbasic cations from the soil as bicarbonates; this increases the percentage of\nAl3+&nbsp; and H+&nbsp; relative to other cations.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Root respiration and\ndecomposition of organic matter by microorganisms releases CO2 which increases\nthe carbonic acid .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plants take up\nnutrients in the form of ions and they often take up more cations than anions.\nHowever plants must maintain a neutral charge in their roots. In order to\ncompensate for the extra positive charge, they will release H+&nbsp; ions from the root. Some plants also exude\norganic acids into the soil to acidify the zone around their roots to help\nsolubilize metal nutrients that are insoluble at neutral pH, such as iron (Fe).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fertilizers react in\nthe soil by the process of nitrification to form nitrate&nbsp; and in the process release H+&nbsp; ions.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The accumulation of\nalkalinity in a soil (as carbonates and bicarbonates of Na, K, Ca and Mg)\noccurs when there is insufficient water flowing through the soils to leach\nsoluble salts. This may be due to arid conditions, or poor internal soil\ndrainage; in these situations most of the water that enters the soil is\ntranspired (taken up by plants) or evaporates, rather than flowing through the\nsoil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The soil pH usually\nincreases when the total alkalinity increases, but the balance of the added\ncations also has a marked effect on the soil pH. For example, increasing the\namount of sodium in an alkaline soil tends to induce dissolution of calcium\ncarbonate, which increases the pH. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plants grown in acid\nsoils can experience a variety of stresses including aluminium (Al), hydrogen\n(H), and/or manganese (Mn) toxicity, as well as nutrient deficiencies of\ncalcium (Ca) and magnesium (Mg).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Aluminium toxicity is\nthe most widespread problem in acid soils. Aluminium is present in all soils,\nbut dissolved Al3+ is toxic to plants; Al3+ is most soluble at low pH; above pH\n5.0, there is little Al in soluble form in most soils.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Aluminium is not a plant\nnutrient, and as such, is not actively taken up by the plants, but enters plant\nroots passively through osmosis. Aluminium inhibits root growth; lateral roots\nand root tips become thickened and roots lack fine branching; root tips may\nturn brown.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the root, the initial effect of Al3+ is the inhibition of the\nexpansion of the cells of the rhizodermis, leading to their rupture; thereafter\nit is known to interfere with many physiological processes including the uptake\nand transport of calcium and other essential nutrients, cell division, cell\nwall formation, and enzyme activity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Strongly alkaline soils\nare sodic and dispersive, with slow infiltration, low hydraulic conductivity\nand poor available water capacity. Plant growth is severely restricted because\naeration is poor when the soil is wet; in dry conditions, plant-available water\nis rapidly depleted and the soils become hard and cloddy (high soil strength).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many strongly acidic\nsoils, on the other hand, have strong aggregation, good internal drainage, and\ngood water-holding characteristics. However, for many plant species, aluminium\ntoxicity severely limits root growth, and moisture stress can occur even when\nthe soil is relatively moist.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Finely ground agricultural lime is often applied\nto acid soils to increase soil pH (liming). The buffering capacity of a soil\ndepends on the clay content of the soil, the type of clay, and the amount of\norganic matter present, and may be related to the soil cation exchange\ncapacity.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soils with high clay content will have a higher buffering capacity\nthan soils with little clay, and soils with high organic matter will have a\nhigher buffering capacity than those with low organic matter. Soils with higher\nbuffering capacity require a greater amount of lime to achieve an equivalent\nchange in pH.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Amendments other than\nagricultural lime that can be used to increase the pH of soil include wood ash,\nindustrial calcium oxide (burnt lime), magnesium oxide, basic slag (calcium\nsilicate), and oyster shells. Calcium silicate neutralizes active acidity in\nthe soil by reacting with H+ ions <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The pH of an alkaline\nsoil can be reduced by adding acidifying agents or acidic organic materials.\nAcidifying fertilizers, such as ammonium sulfate, ammonium nitrate and urea,\ncan help to reduce the pH of a soil because ammonium oxidises to form nitric\nacid. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">An acid is defined as a\nsubstance that tends to release hydrogen ions (H+). Conversely, a base is\ndefined as a substance that releases hydroxyl ions (OH-). All acids contain\nhydrogen ions, and the strength of the acid depends upon the degrees of\nionization (release of hydrogen ions) of the acid.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The more hydrogen ions held\nby the exchange complex of a soil in relation to the basic ions (Ca, Mg, K)\nheld, the greater the acidity of the soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soils become acidic\nwhen basic elements such as calcium, magnesium, sodium and potassium held by\nsoil colloids are replaced by hydrogen ions.
