Soils formed under conditions of\nhigh annual rainfall are more acidic than are soils formed under more arid\nconditions..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rainfall contributes to\na soil\u2019s acidity. Water (H2O) combines with carbon dioxide (CO2) to form a weak\nacid \u2014 carbonic acid (H2CO3). The weak acid ionizes, releasing hydrogen (H+)\nand bicarbonate (HCO3).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The released hydrogen ions replace the calcium ions\nheld by soil colloids, causing the soil to become acidic. The displaced calcium\n(Ca++) ions combine with the bicarbonate ions to form calcium bicarbonate,\nwhich, being soluble, is leached from the soil. The net effect is increased\nsoil acidity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Potassium fertilizers\nhave little or no effect on soil pH.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the ammonium-N in\nfertilizers undergoes nitrification (conversion of ammonium to nitrate in soils\nby bacteria), hydrogen (H+) is released, which can increase acidity.&nbsp; As the percentage of ammonium increases in a given\nfertilizer the acidifying potential will also be increased, thus reducing pH.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Legumes like soybeans,\nalfalfa and clovers tend to take up more cations in proportion to anions. This\ncauses H ions to be released from plant roots to maintain the electrochemical\nbalance within their tissues. The result is a net soil acidification.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even if the top 6\ninches of soil show a pH above 6.0, the subsoil may be extremely acidic. When\nsubsoil pH's drop below 5.0, aluminum and manganese in the soil become much\nmore soluble, and in some soils may be toxic to plant growth. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Liming materials\ncontain calcium and/or magnesium in forms, which when dissolved, will\nneutralize soil acidity. Not all materials containing calcium and magnesium are\ncapable of reducing soil acidity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Extremely and strongly\nacid soils (pH 4.0-5.0) can have high concentrations of soluble aluminum, iron\nand manganese which may be toxic to the growth of some plants. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soils tend to become\nacidic as a result of: (1) rainwater leaching away basic ions (calcium, magnesium,\npotassium and sodium); (2) carbon dioxide from decomposing organic matter and\nroot respiration dissolving in soil water to form a weak organic acid; (3)\nformation of strong organic and inorganic acids, such as nitric and sulfuric\nacid, from decaying organic matter and oxidation of ammonium and sulfur\nfertilizers. Strongly acid soils are usually the result of the action of these\nstrong organic and inorganic acids.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lime is usually added\nto acid soils to increase soil pH. The addition of lime not only replaces\nhydrogen ions and raises soil pH, thereby eliminating most major problems\nassociated with acid soils but it also provides two nutrients, calcium and\nmagnesium to the soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yellowing between the\nveins of young leaves indicates an iron deficiency, a condition arising not\nfrom a lack of iron in the soil but from insufficient soil acidity to put iron\ninto a form that a plant can absorb. Most plants thrive in slightly acidic soil\nbecause that pH affords them good access to all nutrients.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The darker side of soil\npH is plant poisoning.&nbsp; Too low a pH\nlevel can render the plant nutrient manganese available at toxic levels.&nbsp; A pH level that is too low also liberates\naluminum\u2014not a plant nutrient\u2014in amounts that can stunt root growth and\ninterfere with a plant\u2019s uptake of nutrients. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Generally, limestone is\nused to raise a pH level, and sulfur is used to lower it.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;In acidic soils, the availability of nutrients\nsuch as potassium (K), calcium (Ca), and magnesium (Mg) is reduced, while the\namount of potentially toxic elements such as aluminum (Al), iron (Fe), and zinc\n(Zn) is increased. In alkaline soils, iron, manganese (Mn), zinc, and boron (B)\nare commonly deficient.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil pH can be\ntemporarily lowered by adding elemental sulfur. Bacteria in the soil act to\nchange elemental sulfur into sulfuric acid, effectively neutralizing soil\nalkalinity. However, the effects of elemental sulfur are localized to the area\nthat was amended, and the effect is temporary. Soil pH will begin to rise\nshortly after soil bacteria exhaust the added sulfur supply. This effect will\nrequire repeated applications of sulfur to ensure the soil remains at the\ndesired pH.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If too much sulfur is\nadded, or if it is added too frequently, it can actually injure or kill your\nplants. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Well, the pH balance of your soil will let you\nknow which plants you can grow with ease and which plants will be a struggle\nwithout amendments. Knowing your soil\u2019s pH is the secret to knowing what\nnutrients will be in the soil to absorb into the roots of new plants..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Certain plants will\nthrive in acidic soils (0 \u2013 6.5 pH) while others only perform well if the soil\nis alkaline (7.5 \u2013 14). The ideal pH for garden soil is in the neutral range\n(right around 7).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once you know your soil\u2019s pH, you can take measures to fix\nit, or you can choose to grow only the varieties of plants that thrive in your\nsoil type. To amend acidic soil, simply mix in limestone. To amend alkaline\nsoil, add in organic materials such as composted leaves, pine needles, and peat\nmoss.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The effect of pH on a\nsoil is to remove from the soil or to make available certain ions. Soils with\nhigh acidity tend to have toxic amounts of aluminium and manganese. Plants\nwhich need calcium need moderate alkalinity, but most minerals are more soluble\nin acid soils. Soil organisms are hindered by high acidity, and most\nagricultural crops do best with mineral soils of pH 6.5 and organic soils of pH\n5.5.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil organic matter is\nmade up of organic compounds and includes plant, animal and microbial material,\nboth living and dead. A typical soil has a biomass composition of 70%\nmicroorganisms, 22% macrofauna, and 8% roots.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A small part of the\norganic matter consists of the living cells such as bacteria, molds, and\nactinomycetes that work to break down the dead organic matter. Were it not for\nthe action of these micro-organisms, the entire carbon dioxide part of the\natmosphere would be sequestered as organic matter in the soil.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soils that hold\ngenerous amounts of water are less subject to leaching losses of nutrients\nGravitational water is held in large soil pores and rapidly drains out under\nthe action of gravity within a day or so after rain. Plants can only make use\nof gravitational water for a few days after rain.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Capillary water is held\nin pores that are small enough to hold water against gravity, but not so\ntightly that roots cannot absorb it. This water occurs as a film around soil\nparticles and in the pores between them and is the main source of plant\nmoisture. As this water is withdrawn, the larger pores drain first.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The finer\nthe pores, the more resistant they are to removal of water. As water is\nwithdrawn, the film becomes thinner and harder to detach from the soil particles.\nThis capillary water can move in all directions in response to suction and can\nmove upwards through soil for up to two metres, the particles and pores of the\nsoil acting like a wick.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When soil is saturated,\nall the pores are full of water, but after a day, all gravitational water\ndrains out, leaving the soil at field capacity. Plants then draw water out of\nthe capillary pores, readily at first and then with greater difficulty, until\nno more can be withdrawn and the only water left is in the micro-pores. The\nsoil is then at wilting point and without water additions, plants die.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The amount of water\navailable to plants is therefore determined by the capillary porosity and is\ncalculated by the difference in moisture content between field capacity and\nwilting point. This is the total available water storage of the soil. The\nportion of the total available moisture store, which can be extracted by plants\nwithout becoming stressed, is termed readily available water.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The amount of soil\nwater available to plants is governed by the depth of soil that roots can\nexplore (the root zone) and the nature of the soil material. Because the total\nand available moisture storage capacities are linked to porosity, the particle\nsizes (texture) and the arrangement of particles (structure) are the critical\nfactors. Organic matter and carbonate levels and stone content also affect\nmoisture storage.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic matter\nregulates the supply of plant nutrients through its ability to form complexes\nwith metal ions. The term \u2018complex\u2019 covers a number of chemical interactions\nbetween organic matter and metal ions. One of the more important interactions\nis called \u2018chelation\u2019 because of the way part of an organic molecule 'wraps'\nitself around a metal ion, holding it in a claw-like chemical combination.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Available water is the\ndifference between field capacity which is the maximum amount of water the soil\ncan hold and wilting point where the plant can no longer extract water from the\nsoil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water holding capacity\nis the total amount of water a soil can hold at field capacity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plant available water\nis the difference between field capacity (the maximum amount of water the soil\ncan hold) and the wilting point (where the plant can no longer extract water\nfrom the soil) measured over 100 cm or maximum rooting depth .&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Beyond the\nwilting point there is still water in the soil profile, however it is contained\nin pores that are too small for plant roots to access. Soil texture, soil\nstructure and plant rooting depth are the crucial factors in determining the\namount of water available for plants to access.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Increasing clay content\nin the soil profile is associated with greater water holding capacity. However,\nthis does not mean more water is available for plants to use, as the clay helps\ncreate a complex soil matrix of smaller pores which hold water at greater\nsuction pressures <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil aggregates create\npores which store water for plants to access. A poor or non-existent soil\nstructure with high clay content will have a reduced volume of soil pores. The\npores that are present are smaller so water is held at higher suction\npressures, making the plant exert more energy to extract the water, rather than\nusing that energy for yield.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Coarser textured soils\nwill generally have larger pore sizes and little soil structure, resulting in\nrapid water drainage. A lack of soil structure can also mean poor infiltration\nand sometimes a compacted subsurface which can result in waterlogging in the\nroot zone.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In many agricultural\nsoils there are subsoil barriers which prohibit plant roots from accessing\navailable water:--</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Physical barrier \u2013\nsubsurface compaction which may allow the movement of water and nutrients, but\nrestrict root growth.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chemical barrier \u2013\nfactors like subsoil acidity and salinity prevents the plant roots from\naccessing the whole soil profile.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil acts as a sponge\nto take up and retain water. Movement of water into soil is called\ninfiltration, and the downward movement of water within the soil is called\npercolation, permeability or hydraulic conductivity. Pore space in soil is the\nconduit that allows water to infiltrate and percolate. It also serves as the\nstorage compartment for water.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Infiltration rates can\nbe near zero for very clayey and compacted soils, or more than 10 inches per\nhour for sandy and well aggregated soils. Low infiltration rates lead to\nponding on nearly level ground and runoff on sloping ground. Organic matter,\nespecially crop residue and decaying roots, promotes aggregation so that larger\nsoil pores develop, allowing water to infiltrate more readily.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Saturation is the soil water\ncontent when all pores are filled with water. The water content in the soil at\nsaturation is equal to the percent porosity. Field capacity is the soil water\ncontent after the soil has been saturated and allowed to drain freely for about\n24 to 48 hours.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Free drainage occurs because of the force of gravity pulling on\nthe water. When water stops draining, we know that the remaining water is held\nin the soil with a force greater than that of gravity. Permanent wilting point\nis the soil water content when plants have extracted all the water they can. At\nthe permanent wilting point, a plant will wilt and not recover.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Unavailable\nwater is the soil water content that is strongly attached to soil particles and\naggregates, and cannot be extracted by plants. This water is held as films\ncoating soil particles. These terms illustrate soil from its wettest condition\nto its driest condition.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Several terms are used\nto describe the water held between these different water contents.\nGravitational water refers to the amount of water held by the soil between\nsaturation and field capacity.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water holding capacity refers to the amount of\nwater held between field capacity and wilting point. Plant available water is\nthat portion of the water holding capacity that can be absorbed by a plant. As\na general rule, plant available water is considered to be 50 percent of the\nwater holding capacity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water in the form of\nprecipitation or irrigation infiltrates the soil surface. All pores at the soil\nsurface are filled with water before water can begin to move downward. During\ninfiltration, water moves downward from the saturated zone to the unsaturated\nzone.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The interface between these two zones is called the wetting front. When\nprecipitation or irrigation cease, gravitational water will continue to\npercolate until field capacity is reached. Water first percolates through the\nlarge pores between soil particles and aggregates and then into the smaller\npores.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Available water is held\nin soil pores by forces that depend on the size of the pore and the surface\ntension of water. The closer together soil particles or aggregates are, the\nsmaller the pores and the stronger the force holding water in the soil.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because\nthe water in large pores is held with little force, it drains most readily. Likewise,\nplants absorb soil water from the larger pores first because it takes less\nenergy to pull water from large pores than from small pores.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Medium textured soils\n(fine sandy loam, silt loam and silty clay loam) have the highest water holding\ncapacity, while coarse soils (sand, loamy sand and sandy loam) have the lowest\nwater holding capacity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil porosity refers to\nthe space between soil particles, which consists of various amounts of water\nand air. Porosity depends on both soil texture and structure. For example, a\nfine soil has smaller but more numerous pores than a coarse soil. A coarse soil\nhas bigger particles than a fine soil, but it has less porosity, or overall\npore space. Water can be held tighter in small pores than in large ones, so\nfine soils can hold more water than coarse soils.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water infiltration is\nthe movement of water from the soil surface into the soil profile. Soil\ntexture, soil structure, and slope have the largest impact on infiltration\nrate. Water moves by gravity into the open pore spaces in the soil, and the\nsize of the soil particles and their spacing determines how much water can flow\nin.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Wide pore spacing at the soil surface increases the rate of water\ninfiltration, so coarse soils have a higher infiltration rate than fine soils.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A soil's permeability\nis determined by the relative rate of moisture and air movement through the\nmost restrictive layer within the upper 40 inches of the effective root zone.\nWater and air rapidly permeate coarse soils with granular subsoils, which tend\nto be loose when moist and don't restrict water or air movement.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Slow\npermeability is characteristic of a moderately fine subsoil with angular to\nsubangular blocky structure. It is firm when moist and hard when dry.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water-holding capacity\nis controlled primarily by soil texture and organic matter. Soils with smaller\nparticles (silt and clay) have a larger surface area than those with larger\nsand particles, and a large surface area allows a soil to hold more water. In\nother words, a soil with a high percentage of silt and clay particles, which\ndescribes fine soil, has a higher water-holding capacity. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soils are made up of\nthree main components: sand, silt and clay.&nbsp;\nThe proportion of each component determines the soil texture.&nbsp; Each soil texture has its own Water Holding\nCapacity (WHC).&nbsp; The amount of organic\nmatter in the soil also affects water holding capacity to a degree.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water Holding Capacity\nis the ability of a certain soil texture to physically hold water against the\nforce of gravity.&nbsp; It does this by soil\nparticles holding water molecules by the force of cohesion.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Clay particles have the\nability to physically and chemically \u201chold\u201d water molecules to the particle\nmore tightly than sands or silts.&nbsp; Sands\n\u201cgive up\u201d the water between the pores much easier than silts or clays.&nbsp; A good portion of the water \u2013 upwards of 50%\n\u2013 in any soil remains unusable to the plant.&nbsp;\n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The amount of water\nsoil can hold differs based on two variables: --<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">1. Soil texture, which\nindicates the content of particles of various sizes--such as sand, silt, and\nclay--in the soil<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2. Soil organic matter,\nwhich is decayed material that originated from a living organism, plant or\nanimal based<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">You can easily use the\n\"texture by feel\" method to help determine soil texture: <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sand - will feel gritty\nand therefore not hold a lot of water as a result because pores are so large.\nWater can rapidly move through it but not enough water available to plants.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Silt - will feel smooth\nand is the ideal soil texture because of its small pores, which can hold the\nmaximum amount of water with the highest accessibility to plants.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Clay - will feel\nsticky. It can hold a lot of water but will do so tightly in pores so a lower %\nis available to plants.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">IT WAS A PRACTICE FOR\nMILLINIUMS FOR HINDUS TO RECHARGE LAKES WITH CLAY USING LARGE GANESHA IDOLS .\nTHIS IS NOT SUPERSTITION OF SAVAGES..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2014/03/vanishing-lakes-rain-water-harvesting.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2014/03/vanishing-lakes-rain-water-harvesting.html</a></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In terms of soil\ntexture, those made up of smaller particle sizes, such as in the case of silt\nand clay, have larger surface area. The larger the surface area the easier it\nis for the soil to hold onto water so it has a higher water holding capacity.\nSand in contrast has large particle sizes which results in smaller surface\narea. The water holding capacity for sand is low.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; float: left; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/04177296018307800610\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Rn Murthy</a></cite><span class=\"icon user \" style=\"font-weight: bold;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2019/03/questions-from-capt-ajit-vadakayil.html?showComment=1554134611964#c2959043045339315163\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">April 1, 2019 at 9:33 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nDear Capt Ajit sir,<br />\nHere's a man from Kerala Mr RK Nair, settled in Gujarat and created new 40 forests in 7 states...using Miyawaki method...now building Pulwama forest in 40 days with 40000 trees and 40 varieties....receiving 'Glory of India' award...https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/green-hero-meet-malayali-businessman-whos-created-40-forests-7-states-99289</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 36px; margin-top: 1em;\">\n<div class=\"comment-thread inline-thread\" id=\"c2959043045339315163-rt\" style=\"background-color: #eeeeee; margin: 8px 0px; padding: 0.5em 1em;\">\n<ol class=\"thread-chrome thread-expanded\" id=\"c2959043045339315163-ra\" style=\"list-style-type: none; padding: 0px;\">\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"c2685070922522454795\" style=\"border-bottom: 0px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 16px 0px 0px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<img alt=\"\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-QSnd-Z8F7Kc/XFtPudWdwlI/AAAAAAABfq4/vxrkFOO7Iu8Mf6-OaPgw6FPpRDSmMgLdgCK4BGAYYCw/s35/capt%25252BajitC%25252Bvadakayil.JPG\" style=\"border: 1px solid rgb(238, 238, 238); max-width: 36px;\" /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2019/03/questions-from-capt-ajit-vadakayil.html?showComment=1554136301938#c2685070922522454795\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">April 1, 2019 at 10:01 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nSOIL EXPERTS MUST BE INVOLVED IN FOREST PLANTING-- OR IT WILL DO MORE HARM THAN GOOD<br />\n<br />\nYOU CANT PLANT TREES INDISCRIMINATELY LIKE WHAT SADGURU JAGGI VASUDEV DID--WITHOUT EVEN KNOWING LAWS OF TRANSPIRATION OR SOIL DYNAMICS<br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</ol>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil organic matter\n(SOM)&nbsp; can help increase water holding\ncapacity. Soil organic matter has a natural magnetism to water. If the farm\nincreases the percentage of soil organic matter, the soil water holding\ncapacity will increase.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;SOM is decayed material that originated from a living\norganism. SOM can be increased by adding plant or animal material.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sand plays a vital role\nin retaining the water-holding capacity of river and sand mining thus is a\nthreat to the ecosystem as it not only disturbs the river flow but also affects\nthe groundwater level.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Pugs_Fxavtg/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Pugs_Fxavtg?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">Soil degradation due to\nartificial fertilisers / pesticides is slowly turning a third of the world into\ndesert. At this rate, fertile soil will be depleted in 60 years.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Alluvial soil is\nfertile soil deposited by rivers on and near their banks.&nbsp; The most fertile alluvial soil is found in\nthe Ganga valley, where it is deposited by river Ganges. These soils cover\nalmost 35% of the region of India.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These soils are rich in\nminerals especially potash. They are a dark shade of grey and are extremely\nsuitable for agriculture. Some dark black alluvial soil can also be found in\ncoastal areas.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Black Soil are\ncharacterized by their deep black colour. Their composition has a large amount\nof clay. This helps the black soil retain water, making them ideal for crops\nthat require water year round. This also gives them a unique self-ploughing\nability. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These soil are rich in\nlime, iron and magnesia. They are mainly found in the Deccan Plateau in\nMaharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat etc. They are also known as Black Cotton\nSoil, since cotton grows exclusively in black soil, and is one of the main cash\ncrops in India.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Red soil and yellow\nsoil are distinct soils are named after their hues. Red soil gets its colour\nfrom the iron found in its composition in a crystallized form. The soil takes\non a yellow colour when it is hydrated. These soils are generally found in the\nWestern Ghats, Odisha and Chattisgarh.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The clay form of red\nsoil is nutrient rich and viable for forestation. However coarse red or yellow\nsoil has been completely leached of all its nutrients and is not fertile. Red\nsoil actually has a very low level of humus and require fertilizers when used\nfor farming.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Laterite soils are\nfound in regions of high temperature and very high rainfall. The rains will\nwash all the nutrients from the soil, leaving it infertile. The leaching\nprocess will leave behind iron-rich soil, absent of silicon. The humus\ncomposition is also affected by bacteria and fungi that thrive in high\ntemperatures.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Such soils are found in\nthe hot and humid regions of Western Ghats, Eastern Ghats, Malwa Plateau, Tamil\nNadu, Kerala etc. While these soils are not entirely suitable for agriculture\nthey have other uses.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These are the sandy\nsoils that appear in extremely dry and arid regions of Rajasthan and Gujarat.\nThese soils are completely void of any organic matter. They also have a very\nhigh saline content, making them largely infertile. Only desert vegetation\n(cacti, bushes etc) can grow in this type of soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Saline soils also known\nas Usara soils. As the name suggests they have a very high saline content in\ntheir composition. They also have large quantities of potassium and magnesium,\nmaking them infertile. These soils are found both in dry regions and in swamps.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Peaty soils have a very\nhigh content of organic matter and humus. They are seen in regions with high\nrainfall and average temperatures. If there is a lot of vegetation around the\ndead organic matter will accumulate, and in turn, enrich the soil with humus.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These soils also have a\nblack colour and are loamy in texture. There are usually found in parts of\nBihar, Uttranchal, Bengal and Tamil Nadu. And while they are suitable for\nagriculture, these soils need proper care so they do not leach away all their\nnutrients in the heavy rainfall.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One way to keep track\nof the different types of soils found in the world is via soil mapping. These\nmaps show the distribution of the different varieties of soil that can be found\nin a particular area. This helps the farmers with their agriculture, helps the\ngovernment keep a check on soil pollution, helps environmental\nconversationalists, etc.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">PHOSPHATES (containing\nPO43\u2212) are the most common form of phosphorus in natural waters. Phosphates are\nonly moderately soluble and, compared to nitrate, are not very mobile in soils\nand groundwater. Phosphates tend to remain attached to soil particles, but erosion\ncan transport considerable amounts of&nbsp;\nphosphate to streams and lakes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">THE FOAM ON LAKE WATER\nIN BANGALORE IS PRIMARILY DUE TO PHOSPHATES ( PHOSPHORUS )</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Since ancient times\nHindus have surcharges all the lakes in India with an annual load of PHOSLOCK (\nphosphorus locking bentonite clay ) in the form of huge Ganesha clay idols .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">GANESHA IDOLS IMMERSED\nIN LAKES AND RIVERS , ARE TRADITIONALLY MADE WITH BENTONITE CLAY FOR PHOSPHORUS\nLOCKING.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Phosphates are used\nindiscriminately by foreign multinationals( like Procter and Gamble )&nbsp; in their detergents.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Without declaring the\namount or percentage they include more phosphate in detergent in places like\nBangalore were borewell water yields only HARD WATER.&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">So their detergents\nclean better ,&nbsp; Indians buy more , soon\nthey monopolise ,&nbsp; and they laugh all the\nway to the bank.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">But HEY, these rich\nwestern companies sell only PHOSPHATE FREE detergents in USA , Europe and\ndeveloped countries\u2014since at least 20 years.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The phosphate used in\nmost powdered detergents is sodium triphosphate, or STPP, and it's used to\nsoften hard water.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">But when it's\nintroduced to waterways, phosphorous can cause environmental damage, including\nalgae blooms, low oxygen levels , fish deaths\u2014and the foam you see .</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are atmospheric\nconditions which cause more foam on lakes like low atmospheric pressure,&nbsp; wind ripple agitation,&nbsp; rain etc.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Most of the lakes in\nIndia are green in colour due to algae.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Phosphates consume\nlarge amounts of oxygen, in the lake literally killing all&nbsp; aquatic organisms and ecosystems.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Modi govt must\nintroduce a law as soon as possible. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Give these\nmultinational detergent companies a dead line in writing , mentioning the\nINITIAL FINE and the subsequent fine.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">After that make them\nclose shop in India.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Make these\nmultinationals pay for restoration of our lakes. They had double standards.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">People is Bangalore\nstuck with hard borewell water may wonder, how the stains made by hard water on\nglass or stainless steel can be removed.&nbsp;\nTry a little dilute vinegar.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Local cottage industry\ndetergent manufacturers must be helped by the Govt to find an alternative to\nphosphates to reduce water harness and for better wash. Phosphates can be\nreplaced with zeolites (silicate minerals).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Zeolites are\nmicroporous silicate minerals. They bind calcium, magnesium and other metals\npresent in the wash solution and soften the hardness of the wash water. This\nboosts the efficacy of the other cleaning ingredients and increases the\neffectiveness of the detergent.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When used in automatic\ndishwashing detergents, phosphate helped to remove food and grease, reduce spotting\nand filming, control water hardness and suspend the bits of food so they were\nnot redistributed on the dishes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Too much phosphate in\nwater leads to total reduction of good aquatic life, poor taste and odors in\ndrinking water<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Detergent makers have been\ncompeteing with each other to overdose phosphorus . It binds with dirt and\nkeeps it suspended in water, allowing the other cleaning agents to do their\nbest work.&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Phosphorus is more\nimportant in Bangalore where water is exceptionally hard and minerals like\nCalcium, magnesium etc&nbsp; can interfere\nwith cleaning agents.&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the detergents,\nphosphates served as a \"builder\" to improve the detergent's cleaning\nefficiency.&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Builders, such as STPP,\nare important to the cleaning process, as they help to remove dirt from the\nclothes and to minimize soap scum (often seen as a ring on the tub, washing\nmachine, or shirt collars). <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Of the detergent\nbuilders, phosphates were the most popular, because of their CHEAPNESS and\nsuperior cleaning performance. Cheap at the expense of India\u2019s lakes. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These multinationals\nsaved the Western lakes\u2014they did NOT care for India , despite excessive\nprofits.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Phosphate fertilizer is\nmanufactured from rock phosphate. Rock phosphate is mined and processed into\nphosphate fertilizer. India imports lot of it.&nbsp;\n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ships I commanded have\nbrought this from Tampa to Kochi. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Avoid phosphate\nartificial fertilizers near water bodies-&nbsp;\nuse organic fertilizers.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Today many companies\nworldwide manufacture lanthanum-modified bentonite clay (Phoslock) application\nto remove phosphorus from lake water. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Algae can be killed by\nany algecide .&nbsp; But phosphorus is like\nsugar in water and has to be locked and removed by any nano technology..&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Phoslock is a product\ndesigned for phosphate removal from water.&nbsp;\nIts active component is lanthanum which reacts with phosphate forming an\ninsoluble and biologically inert compound.&nbsp;&nbsp;\n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Its ability to bind\nphosphate makes it an effective tool in lake restoration.&nbsp; It is safe for natural aquatic systems.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When used in lake\nrestoration, Phoslock is usually added to the lake as a slurry.&nbsp; As this sinks through the water column it\nbinds phosphate as it goes.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once settled on the\nsediment it can continue to bind phosphate released from the sediment, thus\ncontrolling one of the major blocks to lake restoration - sediment phosphorus\nrelease.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Phoslock can be used in\nlakes , ponds , dam reservoirs as well as other standing waters (e.g. reservoirs,\nfish hatcheries) where high phosphate levels are causing problems.&nbsp; It is not usually applied to flowing waters.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Phoslock is comprised\nof 95% bentonite and 5% lanthanum.&nbsp; It is\nmanufactured through a controlled ion-exchange process whereby cations within\nthe bentonite are exchanged with lanthanum cations.&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The result is that\nlanthanum held within the bentonite structure retains its ability to bind\nphosphate, but does not readily dissociate, i.e. will not form free ions in\nwater.&nbsp; Phoslock works by utilizing the\nability of lanthanum to react with phosphate.&nbsp;\n&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Removal of phosphate by\nlanthanum is highly efficient and has a molar ratio of 1:1 which means that one\nion of lanthanum will bind with one ion of phosphate .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The product of the\nreaction is lanthanum phosphate (LaPO4).&nbsp;\nThe important point is that lanthanum phosphate is highly insoluble\nwhich means it won't dissolve, which in turn means it is not biologically\navailable.&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is the process by\nwhich phosphate (which is dissolved and therefore biologically available) is\nrendered non-biologically available.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One tonne of Phoslock\nis capable of removing 34 kg of phosphate (PO4) or 11 kg of phosphorus\n(P).&nbsp; Phosphate is an important food\nsource of algae (particularly blue green algae).&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By removing phosphate\nfrom the water column and preventing its release from sediments, Phoslock\nessentially deprives algae of an important food source and the proliferation of\nalgae, particularly blue green algae, is reduced. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Both nitrogen and\nphosphorus are important nutrients for algal growth, however the growth of blue\ngreen algae is generally not limited by the concentration of nitrogen as many\nspecies of blue green algae can fix and store nitrogen from the atmosphere. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;The proliferation of blue green algae in a\nwater body is related to the competitive advantage they have over other\nphytoplankton groups (such as diatoms and green algae) when excess phosphorus\nis available in the water.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The kinetic uptake of\nphosphate by Phoslock varies to some degree according to water chemistry,\nhowever in most situations, more than 90% of available phosphate is bound\nwithin three hours of an application of Phoslock.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Unlike other methods of\nbinding phosphate (such as iron and aluminium salts), an application of\nPhoslock will have no effect on either the pH or the conductivity of the water\nbody.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Following the\napplication of Phoslock to a water body, any phosphate that has reacted with\nthe lanthanum in the clay will remain permanently bound.&nbsp; Furthermore, any lanthanum sites in the clay\nmatrix that have not reacted with phosphate remain active and will continue to\nbind phosphate (from both external and internal sources) until saturated.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This means that an\napplication of Phoslock can be designed to achieve a sustained reduction in\nphosphate levels. Phoslock is the commercial name for a bentonite clay in which\nthe sodium and/or calcium ions are exchanged for lanthanum. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The addition of this\nelement allows it to bind with phosphates to form rhabdophane and thereby\nremove them from the water column.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Phoslock permanently\nlocks phosphorus into an inert mineral that sinks to the bottom and becomes\npart of the pond's natural sediments. Any unreacted lanthanum remains imbedded\nin the bentonite granules, which settle to the bottom of the pond, that will continue\nto bond and sequester phosphorus as it releases from the sediments.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cottage industries must\nbe taught to replace phosphates from their products with non-phosphate\nalternatives, such as zeolite A, sodium carbonate, citrates, and sodium\nsilicate.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Harmful algal blooms\n(HABs) are can be caused by many different types of algae in freshwater\necosystems, and can be triggered by nutrient enrichment. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The most frequent and\nsevere blooms typically are caused by cyanobacteria, the only known freshwater\nalgae with the potential for production of toxins potent enough to harm human\nhealth.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">CyanoHABs can threaten human and aquatic ecosystem health.&nbsp; Economic damages related to cyanoHABs include\nthe loss of recreational revenue, decreased property values, and increased\ndrinking-water treatment costs.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot;
